TABREF201.text: Long-Term Indomethacin (LIT) Exposure Is Safe for the Fetus. Ozhan M Turan, 1 Coleen Driscoll, 2 Rinat Gabbay_Benziv, 1 Sifa Turan, 1 Chris R Harman. 1 1 Obstetrics, Gynecology & Reproductive Sciences, University of Maryland, Baltimore, MD, USA; 2 Neonatology, University of Maryland, Baltimore, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION: Indomethacin use in pregnancy generates conflicting views.Our study examines safety of antenatal indomethacin when it is extended beyond 48-72h, in women with cervical shortening. METHODS: Cohort study of fetuses treated under our LIT protocol: Women with progressive cervical shortening <25mm before 24w. Oral indomethacin: 100mg loading, 50mg qid upto 48h, 25mg qid. Monitored weekly for oligohydramnios and ductus arteriosus (DA) constriction. LIT was stopped automatically at 32w, earlier for complications. Pulmonary hemorrhage, patent DA, necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), spontaneous intestinal perforation (SIP), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) Grade III-IV, other intracranial hemorrhage (IH), thrombocytopenia (platelet <150K), anemia (Hb<13 g/dl), acute kidney injury (AKI:creatinine>1.5mg/ dl and urine output <1ml/h) at delivery and 4-5 days of life were noted. Outcome was compared to babies with similar presentation who received no indomethacin. RESULTS: LIT was used in 197 cases. There were 89 controls. LIT began at mean 22.2w; median duration was 52 (4-108)d. 1 fetus (0.5%) had DA constriction-LIT was stopped, no treatment needed. Four (2.3%) had oligohydramnios at 25-26w (6-15d after LIT started), delivering at 27.2-37.1w, after LIT was stopped. Controls' weight and gestetational age (GA) at birth didnot differ from LIT cases. Individual complications didnot differ vs controls.Total IVH+IH was not significantly different. Complications were numerically more in the LIT group, but even the composite of ALL complications was not significantly different (p>0.05). By logistic regression, only GA contributed meaningfully to complications (p< 0.0001) CONCLUSIONS: LIT, for 7-8 weeks on average, didnot increase fetal or neonatal problems when used in this protocol. The safety demonstrated here is permissive to an RCT of indomethacin in prevention of preterm birth.Importance of Fetal Fraction Analysis for cfDNA Testing in theGeneral Pregnancy Population. Eric Wang, 1 Craig Struble, 1 Christopher Kingsley, 1 Rhoberta Steeke, 3 Annette Batey, 2 Desiree Hollemon, 2 Arnold Oliphant, 4 Thomas Musci. 2 1 Bioinformatics, Ariosa Diagnostics, Inc, San Jose, CA, USA; 2 Medical Affairs, Ariosa Diagnostics, Inc, San Jose, CA, USA; 3 Informatics, Ariosa Diagnostics, Inc, San Jose, CA, USA; 4 CSO, Ariosa Diagnostics, Inc, San Jose, CA, USA. INTRODUCTION: The Harmony TM Prenatal Test uses an assay method, Digital Analysis of Selected Regions (DANSR TM), for analysis of chromosomes 13, 18, 21, X and Y as well as other chromosomes to measure fetal fraction. Products from the DANSR assay are then analyzed with the Fetal fraction Optimized Risk of Trisomy Evaluation (FORTE TM ) algorithm to assess patient-specific risk of trisomy. Alternative tests, such as those using massively parallel shotgun sequencing, use a Z-statistic or Normalized Chromosome Value (NCV) to discriminate between normal and abnormal chromosomal counts without accounting for fetal fraction. METHODS: A general pregnancy population cohort of 15,841 women between 10.0 to 14.3 weeks gestation were followed to pregnancy outcome. Z-statistics were computed using previously described standard Z-test of proportions and compared to FORTE risk scores generated by the Harmony test. A Z-statistic of ≥ 3 was considered 'Positive' for trisomy and a FORTE risk score of ≥ 1% was 'High Risk' for trisomy.RESULTS:The cohort included 38 cases of trisomy 21 (T21) and 10 cases of trisomy 18 (T18). A subset of participants (n = 11,185) had trisomy 13 (T13) analysis.

TABREF203.text: Distribution of Cord Blood Monocyte Subtypes in Preeclampsia andIntrauterine Fetal Growth Restriction. Thushari I Alahakoon, 1,2 Heather Medbury, 1,3 Helen Williams, 1,3 Nicole Fewings, 1,4 Xin M Wang, 1,5 Vincent W Lee. 1,6 1 Sydney Medical School, University of Sydney, Sydney, NSW, Australia; 2 Department of Maternal Fetal Medicine, Westmead Hospital, Westmead, NSW, Australia; 3 Department of Surgery, Westmead Hospital, Westmead, NSW, Australia; 4 Department of Immunology, Westmead Hospital, Westmead, NSW, Australia; 5 Flow cytometry Core Facility, Westmead Research Hub, Westmead, NSW, Australia; 6 Department of Renal Medicine, Westmead Hospital, Westmead, NSW, Australia. INTRODUCTION:Fetal monocytes are present in fetal and placental circulations and have the opportunity to play significant roles including: homeostasis, immune defense, and tissue repair. There is little available data on fetal monocyte phenotype and function. They may play a role in pathogenesis of pregnancy complications including preeclampsia (PE) and intrauterine fetal growth restriction (IUGR). In this pilot study we aimed to describe the cord blood monocyte subset phenotype in normal pregnancy and in pregnancy complications such as PE and IUGR. METHODS: A prospective cross-sectional case control study was conducted. Cord blood samples from 26 pregnancies were collected at delivery from normal pregnancy, PE, IUGR and PE with IUGR. The distribution of fetal monocyte subtypes was characterized by CD14 and CD16 expression using flow cytometry and compared for each clinical group using a classification of classical, intermediate and non-classical subtypes. RESULTS: There is a trend towards an increase in the intermediate and non-classical monocyte subsets in the cord blood of PE, IUGR and PE+IUGR as compared to the normal pregnancies which reached statistical significance for the non-classical subset. The intermediate monocytes were the dominant monocyte subtype in the cord blood of PE, IUGR and PE+IUGR as opposed to a predominance of classical subtypes in normal pregnancy and adults. *Figure(s) will be available online. CONCLUSIONS: We have documented for the first time in cord blood of PE and IUGR, a distinctive monocyte subset distribution with the intermediate subset dominating. Fetal monocytes may play a significant role in the pathogenesis of PE and IUGR and further study is warranted into their phenotype and function.Expression of Inflammatory Markers in Women WithSymptoms of Perinatal Depression. This information should be used for evaluation and counseling of women with advanced maternal age, especially in those planning a pregnancy and or seeking assisted reproductive conception.Pregnancy Outcomes Between Superimposed PreeclampsiaWith and Without Severe Features -Evaluation of the New ACOG Task Force Guidelines. Hind N Moussa, Mateo G Leon, Ana Marti, Claudia Pedroza, Sean C Blackwell, Baha M Sibai. Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Reproductive Sciences, The University of Texas Medical School, Houston, TX, USA. INTRODUCTION: The ACOG task force (TF) on hypertension (HTN) in pregnancy introduced a new definition of superimposed preeclampsia (SIP) adding severe features (SF) as new criteria.The TF recommended that those with SIP be delivered ³37 wks, whereas those with SF be delivered £34 wks. Our aim was to investigate the validity of this new definition by comparing pregnancy adverse outcomes in SIP with and without SF. METHODS: Women with chronic HTN and singleton pregnancies enrolled in a multicenter trial were studied. SIP was reclassified according to the new definition to SIP and SIP-SF (persistent systolic BP > 160 or diastolic BP >110, plts < 100K, LFTs >70, Cr > 1.1, or persistent CNS/ abdominal symptoms). Composite adverse outcomes including rates of total and indicated preterm birth, abruptio, postpartum hemorrhage, and maternal and perinatal death were compared by X2. Adjustment was done with a multivariate logistic-regression analysis and all statistical tests were two-sided. RESULTS: 763 patients met inclusion criteria, and 216 (27%) had SIP. 129 (17%) had a diagnosis of SIP and 87 (11%) had SIP-SF. Baseline characteristics including maternal age, baseline BP, and assignment to low dose aspirin were similar between both groups. Using univariate analysis, the composite adverse outcome was higher among the SIP-SF group (p=0.04), as well as indicated preterm birth (p=0.02), cesarean section (p=0.02), and SGA (p=0.02). After adjustment, composite adverse outcomes were similar in both groups, however, SGA was higher among SIP-SF (aOR3.12, p=0.02).

TABREF209.text: Pregnancy Outcomes Following a Computer-Delivered Brief Intervention for Alcohol Use During Pregnancy: Results From a PilotRandomized Trial. Steven J Ondersma, 1 Jessica R Beatty, 1 Dace S Svikis, 2 Grace Chang, 3 Golfo K Tzilos, 4 Ronald C Strickler, 5 Shetoya Rice, 1 Amy E Graham, 1 Robert J Sokol. 6 1 Merrill Palmer Skillman Institute, Wayne State Univeristy, Detroit, MI, USA; 2 Institute for Women's Health; AWHARE, Virginia Commonwealth Univeristy, Richmond, VA, USA; 3 VA Boston Healthcare System, Harvard Medical School, Cambridge, MA, USA; 4 Department of Psychiatry & Human Behavior, Brown Univeristy, Providence, RI, USA; 5 Education & Research; Gynecology, Obstetrics, Women's Health, Henry Ford Health System, Detroit, MI, USA; 6 C.S. Mott Center for Human Growth and Development, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, USA. INTRODUCTION:Computer-delivered brief interventions (CBIs) are a promising option for addressing alcohol use in antenatal care settings; they provide consistent screening and evidence-based brief interventions at low cost without requiring substantial time and effort from medical staff. Prior analyses of the effects of an empathic, interactive, and tailored singlesession CBI on maternal alcohol use showed 90-day period prevalence abstinence rates of 90% for the CBI group, vs. 74% for controls (OR = 3.4, p = 0.19). The current secondary analysis focuses on pregnancy outcomes, with a positive outcome defined as a live birth > 2500g without NICU admission. METHODS: Phase I parallel groups randomized trial. Forty-eight T-ACE positive pregnant women were recruited from a Henry Ford Hospital prenatal clinic in Detroit, and randomly assigned to a single, 20-minute CBI plus three tailored mailings (n = 24) or to an attention control condition (n = 24). Participants were primarily low income and African-American (n = 39, 81%), with mean gestational age of 12 weeks at baseline/randomization. RESULTS: Blinded review of participants' electronic medical records revealed positive pregnancy outcomes in 19 of 23 CBI participants for whom data were available (82.6%), vs. 14 of 23 control group participants (60.9%; p = 0.09). Examination of subcomponents revealed no differences in miscarriage(2 ineach group [8.7%]). Fewer CBI infants had an NICU admission (1 [4.5%] vs. 3 [13.6%]) or low birthweight (0 vs. 4 [20%]). CONCLUSIONS: These preliminary findings suggest that CBIs for alcohol use in pregnancy may result in better pregnancy outcomes. Development of a Non-Obese Mouse Dietary Model of Gestational Diabetes. Kathleen A Pennington, Kelly E Pollock, Jennifer A Kaiser, Laura C Schulz. Obstetrics, Gynecology and Women's Health, University of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA. INTRODUCTION: Gestational diabetes mellitus(GDM)is defined as diabetes that begins during pregnancy, and it usually resolves after parturition. It has both immediate and long term impacts on metabolic and cardiovascular health of the mother and fetus. GDM is one of the most common obstetrical complications, affecting 7-18% of all pregnancies. Despite its high prevalence, there is no widely accepted animal model. Previous studies in rodents have shown that a high fat diet (HFD) for 1 month before pregnancy induces obesity and type II diabetes. Other laboratories have used the heterozygous leptin receptor mutant (Lepr db/+ ) as a model of GDM, but our laboratory and others were unable to replicate this. We therefore set out to develop a mouse model of GDM. METHODS: Wild type (Wt) C57B6/J and Lepr db/+ mice were placed on either a control (CD) or 45% fat diet (HFD) from either one or three weeks prior to mating and throughout pregnancy. At d17.5 glucose tolerance tests were performed, and serum was collected for leptin and insulin measurement. RESULTS: Regardless of genotype, mice placed on a HFD one week prior to mating developed GDM [Area under the curve 12500 + 721(Wt CD) vs. 23900 + 2900 (Wt 1WkHFD), 1360 + 435 (Lepr db/+ CD) vs. 2300 + 933 (Lepr db/+ 1WkHFD)] (2-way ANOVA, diet p<0.001). Weights differed by genotype (P<0.0001), but not diet: Wt CD (31.26±0.93g) vs. WT HFD (31.13±0.78g) and Lepr db/+ CD (36.53±0.80g) vs. Lepr db/+ HFD (38.22±0.80g). Glucose tolerance was not significantly impaired in mice placed on a HFD 3 weeks prior to mating (AUC WT 3WkHD 15600 + 1430 vs. Lepr db/+ 3WkHFD 17500 + 2500), suggesting adaptation to the HFD over time. CONCLUSIONS: In conclusion, we have developed a novel model of GDM with no obesity and no diabetes prior to pregnancy. Future studies will use this model to characterize the effects of GDM on offspring and maternal health. Indigenous Australian women are twice as likely to develop pregnancy complications such as preeclampsia, preterm birth and IUGR.

TABREF211.text: Significant Differences in the Diurnal Blood Pressure <20 Weeks Gestation Between Women Who Developed Pre-Eclampsia andThose Who Did Not. Emma Shawkat, 1,2 Edward Johnstone, 1,2 Catherine Chmiel, 1 Giovanna Bernatavicius, 1 Jenny Myers. 1,2 1 Maternal & Fetal Health Research Centre, Saint Mary's Hospital, Manchester, United Kingdom; 2 Obstetrics & Gynaecology, Central Manchester NHS Trust, Manchester, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: Most people have a reduction in their nighttime blood pressure (BP) of >10%, these individuals are known as 'dippers'.In the pregnant population loss of the nocturnal dip has been associated with pre-eclampsia (PE). 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) is routinely used in the non-pregnant population as a confirmative diagnostic tool. It provides valuable additional information over standard BP measurement including circadian variation in BP. Despite these advantages there is no current defined role for 24-hour ABPM in pregnancy. The aim of this study was to compare the 24-hour BP profiles of women at high risk of developing PE. METHODS: Nineteen women <20 weeks gestation attending the Manchester Antenatal Vascular Services (MAViS) research clinic who required antihypertensive medication, or had a standard BP close to target or treatment threshold underwent 24-hour ABPM. ABPM was recorded half hourly during the day and hourly at night with a SpaceLabs 92017a-1. Wake, sleep and drug ingestion times were self-reported. RESULTS: Of the 19 women examined 15 had essential hypertension, 9 had uncomplicated pregnancy outcomes, 9 developed PE and 1 pregnancy was complicated by fetal growth restriction (FGR).

TABREF212.text: Intrauterine Hypoxia Generates Placental Insufficiency in the Pregnant Guinea Pig.Loren P Thompson, 1 Bhanu Telugu, 2 Laramie Pence, 2 Gerard Pinkas. 1 1 Obstet,Gyn, & Reprod Sci, Univ. of MD,  Baltimore, MD, USA; 2 Animal Science, Univ. of MD, College Park,  MD, USA.   INTRODUCTION: Intrauterine hypoxia is one of most challenging conditions during pregnancy and fetal development. Placental hypoxia can alter extravillous trophoblast (EVT) invasion, disrupt normal spiral artery remodeling, reduce perfusion, and contribute to fetal growth restriction. Since the pregnant guinea pig (GP) placenta closely mimics human placental morphology and EVT invasion, we propose to develop a pregnant GP model to study the underlying mechanisms associated with the placental response to in utero hypoxia. METHODS: Pregnant GPs were maintained in either normoxia (NMX; N=10) or placed in a hypoxic chamber of differing O 2 levels (HPX; 16%, N=4; 12%, N=5; 10.5%O 2 , N=10) at 30d gestation (after implantation and before EVT invasion) until term. At 64d gestation (term=65d), pregnant GPs were anesthetized, mean brachial artery blood pressures (MAP) measured, placentas and fetuses excised, and fetal organs (heart, brain, liver, kidney) weighed. Placentas were fixed for histology and Placental Growth Factor (PGF) mRNA levels measured by qPCR. RESULTS: At near term(64 d), maternal MAP (mmHg; mean±SE) of NMX GPs was 40.4±2.4. MAPs were increased (P<0.001) with HPX at 10.5% O 2 (57.9±2.4) but not at 16% (45.8±2.4) or 12%O 2 (44.2±2.1) compared to NMX controls. Fetal body weight (FBW, g) progressively decreased with HPX severity (85.5±2.0 vs 85.5±3.7 vs 78.6±3.8 vs 71.7±1.9; NMX vs 16% vs 12% vs 10.5%O 2 ; respectively, P<0.05 vs 10.5% only). Asymmetric growth restriction was indicated by a HPXinduced increase (P<0.05) in fetal heart/FBW ratios by 13% (at 12% and 10.5%O 2 ) and brain/FBW ratios by 11.2% (at 10.5%O 2 ) and no change in relative liver or kidney weight. HPX at 10.5%O 2 increased (P<0.05) placenta wt by 10.1%, relative placenta wt by 31.8%, PGF mRNA levels by 2.2 fold (0.005±0.001 vs 0.011±0.002 expression ratio; NMX vs HPX), and exhibited compaction of the placental labyrinth compared to NMX. CONCLUSIONS: Chronic intrauterine hypoxia stimulates placenta growth as a compensatory response to the reduced oxygenation although may negatively impact spiral artery remodeling. The placental growth is insufficient to prevent growth restriction of the fetus and may contribute to maternal hypertension. We conclude that intrauterine hypoxia generates placental insufficiency in the pregnant GP, making it a useful model for investigating altered EVT invasion. (Supported by UMD-UMBC Seed Grant).Vasodilatory Responses To CGRP Family Peptides and Their Receptor Levels in Human OmentalArteries Are Increased During Pregnancy. Ancizar Betancourt, Madhu Chauhan, Yuanlin Dong, Meena Balakrishnan, Mathew Anderson, Michael Belfort, Chandra Yallampalli. OB/GYN, Baylor College of Medicine/Texas Children's Hospital, Houston, TX, USA. INTRODUCTION: Calcitonin gene related peptide (CGRP) and its family members adrenomedullin (AM) and intermedin (IMD) play important roles in maintaining vascular adaptation during pregnancy, but their effect on human omental arteries (OA), are unknown. The aim of this study was to determine if vasodilatory responses of OA to CGRP family peptides and the expression of their receptor components in OA are elevated during pregnancy.METHODS:Omental arteries, were collected from non-pregnant(NP) women (n=8) during laporatomy and term pregnant (P) women (n=9) at caesarian section. The OA were cleaned, cut into rings and mounted on a wire myograph. Rings were pre-contracted with U46619 (1µM), and relaxation responses to CGRP AM and IMD (0.1nM -100nM), and bradykinin (BK, 0.1nM -1µM), as percent inhibition of U46619 induced contraction were assessed. Cellular localization and mRNA expression of CRLR and RAMP1, 2, and 3 in OA were assessed by immunofluorescence and Real-time QPCR.

INTRODUCTION: Ranitidine is commonly used for the treatment of gastro-esophageal reflux during pregnancy. Physiological changes during pregnancy may alter the pharmacokinetics of ranitidine. This study was designed to determine if pharmacokinetics of ranitidine change during pregnancy.

TABREF216.text: CONCLUSIONS:Our study demonstrates that pregnancy does not alter the pharmacokinetics of ranitidine.Maternal Supplementation With Dietary Inorganic Nitrate Improves Uteroplacental Vascular Function in eNOS -/-Mice. Elizabeth Cottrell, 1 Ainslie Garrod, 1 Sarah Finn-Sell, 1 Mark Wareing, 1 Elizabeth Cowley, 1 Susan Greenwood, 1 Philip N Baker, 2 Colin Sibley. 1 1 Maternal and Fetal Health Research Centre, University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom; 2 Liggins Institute, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand. INTRODUCTION:Epidemiological studies show that consumption of a diet high in fruits and vegetables during pregnancy is beneficial. However, the specific factors underlying these associations are not well understood. Diets high in vegetables provide both anti-oxidants and significant amounts of inorganic nitrate. Dietary nitrate is an important modulator of cardiovascular function in non-pregnant humans and animals, providing an exogenous source of nitric oxide (NO) that can improve blood flow and reduce damage caused by ischemia-reperfusion injury. In FGR pregnancies, reduced NO production and/or bioavailability is reported.Here we tested the hypothesis that maternal nitrate supplementation during pregnancy would increase NO bioavailability and action, and improve vascular function and fetal growth in a mouse model of FGR, the endothelial nitric oxide synthase knockout (eNOS -/-) mouse. METHODS: Pregnant C57Bl/6J (wildtype) and eNOS -/mice were supplemented with nitrate-containing beetroot juice (BR+) in the drinking water from embryonic day (E)12.5, to deliver ~1mmol/kg/day inorganic nitrate. Control mice received an isocaloric dose of apple juice (AJ) or an equivalent dose of nitrate-depleted beetroot juice (BR-). At E18.5, fetal and placental weights were measured and maternal uterine arteries (UtA) isolated. UtA contraction (phenylephrine [PE]; 0.1-10000nM) and endothelium-dependent relaxation (acetylcholine [Ach]; 0.1-10000nM) were assessed by wire myography. RESULTS: Supplementation of pregnant eNOS -/mice with BR+ improved maternal UtA vascular function. UtA of BR+ mice exhibited reduced contraction to PE (p<0.05) and increased relaxation to Ach (p<0.01) compared with those from AJ control mice. Contraction and relaxation responses of UtA from BR-mice were not different from AJ controls, indicating the nitrate-dependence of BR+ effects. CONCLUSIONS: Dietary nitrate supplementation improves uteroplacental vascular function in a mouse model of FGR. Ongoing studies aim to determine the mechanisms underlying these beneficial effects.Mechanisms Underlying CGRP Family Peptides-InducedVasorelaxation of Human Omental Arteries During Pregnancy. TABREF219.text: Cerebral Blood Flow Changes Over Pregnancy in WomenWith a History of HELLP Syndrome and Those With Prior Preeclampsia. David J Hermel, 1 Erin A Morris, 1 Richard Watts, 2 Ira M Bernstein. 1 1 Obstetrics, Gynecology & Reproductive Sciences, UVM College of Medicine, Burlington, VT, USA; 2 Radiology, UVM College of Medicine, Burlington, VT, USA.

TABREF220.text: All subjects had detailed cardiovascular phenotyping both PP and 3P. Data are presented as mean±sd. Statistical analyses were performed using paired, across group techniques with p<.05 accepted for significance. RESULTS: HELLP and PRE were not significantly different with respect to age, BMI, interval since last delivery or cycle day studied (p=.27-.96). Prior affected pregnancies were delivered at similar gestational ages with similar incidences of IUGR (50% per group). In HELLP we observed a decrease in cerebral blood flow in the thalamus over the course of subsequent pregnancies (-27.96±25.5 mL/100g tissue/min, p=.025), with all other lobes showing trends toward decreased cerebral blood flow (temporal -13.77±11.5, p=.06; frontal -9.4±11.9, p=0.12; occipital -18.95±14.2, p=.14; parietal -12.5±11.3, p=.11). In contrast, cerebral blood flow in PRE remained relatively unchanged over pregnancy in all regions interrogated (temporal -0.68±10.1; frontal 0.39±7.2; occipital -4.37±17.1; parietal -1.56±10.3). Among all subjects, there was a positive correlation between frontal lobe blood flow changes and percent plasma volume expansion as a function of lean body mass (r=.593, p=.038). CONCLUSIONS: Cerebral perfusion studies demonstrate significant posterior circulation changes, evident by thalamic blood flow variation, between women with a history of HELLP and PRE. Changes in plasma volume over pregnancy appear to be associated with changes in cerebral blood flow, specifically in the frontal lobe. These unique hemodynamic features identified in pregnancy in women with a history of HELLP compared with prior PRE, if present in other vascular beds, may help explain unique clinical features associated with HELLP syndrome.Elucidation of the Role of the DDAH/ADMA/NO Axis in Pregnancy-Related Haemodynamic Adaptation. Laura Howe, 1,2 Julia Zollner, 1,2 James Leiper, 2 Mark R Johnson. 1 1 S&C,IRDB, Imperial College, London,  United Kingdom; 2 NOS Signalling Group, CSC, MRC, London, United  Kingdom.

TABREF221.text: Young Nulliparous Women. Lindsay S Howe, 1 Erin A Morris, 1 Carole A McBride, 1 Gary J Badger, 1 Ira M Bernstein. 2 1 Obstetrics, Gynecology & Reproductive Sciences, UVM, Burlington, VT, USA; 2 Medical Biostatistics, UVM, Burlington, VT, USA. INTRODUCTION:Obesity is associated with cardiovascular complications including preeclampsia, hypertension, and CVD. We sought to determine the association of obesity and fat distribution (determined by DEXA) on hemodynamic variables linked to an increased risk for preeclampsia when observed prior to pregnancy. METHODS: We evaluated 79 healthy nulliparous woman, aged 30±4 years. Obesity was indexed as both BMI and body composition (both total percent body fat, (%BF) and central android % fat (%ABF) determined by DEXA). Spearman correlation coefficients were used to assess relationships between BMI, %BF, and %ABF with blood pressure (BP), pulse (P), pulse wave velocity (PWV), cardiac output (CO), and uterine blood flow (UBF). T-tests were used to compare morbidly obese subjects (MO > 40% body fat) with normal-weight subjects (NW <30% body fat). P< .05 was accepted for significance. RESULTS: BMI was moderately correlated with DEXA derived indices of fat (%BF r=.78 p<.001, %ABF r=.74 p<0.001). %ABF and %BF were strongly associated (r=.95, p<.001) BMI was associated with increased P (r=.31, p<.01), diastolic BP (r=.22, p<.05) andCO (r=.31, p=.005). %ABF was associated with increased P (r=.40, p<.001), PWV (r=.31, p<.01) and CO (r=.25, p<.05) %BF and %ABF had similar associations. In direct comparisons MO subjects had higher P (MO: 66 + 8, NW: 58 + 7 bpm, p<.001) PWV (MO: 4.4±.5, NW: 4.1±.4 m/s, p<.05), and CO (MO: 4.9±1.0, NW: 4.2±.8 L/min, p<.01) than NW subjects.

TABREF223.text: Factors Influencing Early Pregnancy Uterine Arterial Blood Flow andResistance Index. Carole A McBride, 1 Gary J Badger, 2 Erin A Morris, 1 Ira M Bernstein. 1 1 Obstetrics, Gynecology & Reproductive Sciences, University of Vermont College of Medicine, Burlington, VT, USA; 2 Medical Biostatistics, University of Vermont, Burlington, VT, USA. INTRODUCTION:Uterine artery hemodynamic abnormalities in early pregnancy are associated with fetal growth restriction and preeclampsia. The factors that influence early pregnancy uterine artery blood flow (UBF) and resistance index (RI) are not well understood. METHODS: We evaluated 40 healthy, nulliparous young women (age 30±4 years, BMI 24±6 kg/m 2) ) both prepregnancy (PP) and again at 12-14 weeks of pregnancy (EP). Subjects were evaluated PP in the follicular phase (cycle day 9±3), subsequently conceived singletons, and were re-evaluated in EP at mean gestational age (GA) 91±5 days. Evaluations followed overnight fasts. Volumetric UBF and RI were measured bilaterally using transvaginal Doppler ultrasound. DEXA scans were used to evaluate body composition. Additional PP physiologic variables included pulse wave velocity (PWV), plasma volume corrected for lean body mass (PV/LBM) and measures of obesity. Prior early pregnancy loss was ascertained from clinical histories. Stepwise regression models examined EP UBF and RI, and the change in UBF and RI from PP to EP as dependent variables. Data are expressed as mean ± SD with p<0.10 accepted for significance for model contributors. RESULTS: Increased EP UBF was associated with prior early pregnancy loss (R 2 =0.15, p=.02), higher PP PV/LBM (R 2 =0.13, p=.02), and higher GA at observation (R 2 =0.08, p=.06). Surprisingly, PP UBF was not a significant contributor to EP UBF. The same factors contributed similarly to changes in UBF from PP to EP. RI in EP was highest in women with >40% body fat (R 2 =0.09, p=.07), and change in RI was associated with PP RI (R 2 =0.36, p<.0001) and fat mass (R 2 =0.07, p=.05) CONCLUSIONS: Increased EP UBF is observed in women who have experienced prior early pregnancy loss, despite no observable difference in PP UBF. Increased EP UBF is also associated with increased PP PV/ LBM. Uterine artery RI is higher in obese women this association with obesity is observed both PP and EP. Lower RI in EP is inversely associated with PP RI and obesity. For women in their first ongoing pregnancy, prior pregnancy, regardless of length, appears to result in enhanced uterine artery vascular remodeling. Additionally obesity appears to contribute to early uterine hemodynamic adaptations and may contribute to adverse pregnancy outcome.Prepregnancy Blood Pressure and History of First Trimester LossContribute To Birth Weight and Placental Weight. Erin A Morris, 1 Carole A McBride, 1 Gary J Badger, 2 Ira M Bernstein. 1 1 Obstetrics, Gynecology & Reproductive Sciences, UVM College of Medicine, Burlington, VT, USA; 2 Medical Biostatistics, UVM, Burlington, VT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Evidence suggests maternal cardiovascular fitness is an important component of successful pregnancy outcome.Our aim was to determine the association of prepregnancy cardiovascular physiology on outcomes of birthweight (BW) and placental weight. METHODS: 34 healthy nulliparous women were enrolled in a longitudinal study prior to planned pregnancy. A detailed cardiovascular assessment was performed during the follicular phase. Blood pressure was measured in the seated position with continuous non-invasive tonometric radial artery monitoring. Cardiac output (CO), uterine blood flow (UBF), plasma volume (PV) and pulse wave velocity (PWV) were also examined. Univariate and stepwise multivariate regressions were used to determine associations of cardiovascular variables with BW and placental weight. Data are expressed as mean±sd, with significance at p<.05. RESULTS: The mean age of participants was 30±4 years, with mean BMI of 24.3±5.7. 11 women had histories of prior first trimester loss. Mean gestational age (GA) at delivery was 278±10 days with mean BW of 3476±506g and mean placental weight of 482±89g. Significant independent contributors to BW included: GA at delivery (r 2 0.34, p=.0003), infant sex (r 2 0.16, p=.004), maternal height (r 2 .09, p=.015), diastolic blood pressure (DBP) (r 2 .06, p=.034) and history of first trimester pregnancy loss (r 2 .05, p=.036). Male infants had higher BW than female infants (3673±470g, 3159±399g, p=.002). This regression model accounted for 70% of variation in BW. Prior first trimester pregnancy loss and DBP were also significant independent contributors to placental weight (r 2 .141, .174, p=.041, .014), contributing to 32% of variation in placental weight. DBP had a negative correlation with both BW and placental weight such that lower prepregnancy DBP was associated with higher BW and placental weight. Prepregnancy CO, UBF, PV and PWV were not found to be independent contributors to BW or placental weight. CONCLUSIONS: Prepregnancy DBP and prior first trimester pregnancy loss are significant independent contributors to BW and placental weight. These findings may highlight the importance of low systemic vascular resistance for optimal placentation and fetal growth. Our findings suggest that a previous pregnancy, even if it ends in the first trimester, may have a lasting favorable effect on the uterine environment.Persistence of Pregnancy-Induced Maternal Uterine VascularRemodeling in Rodents. Erin A Morris, George Osol. Obstetrics, Gynecology & Reproductive Sciences, UVM College of Medicine, Burlington, VT, USA. INTRODUCTION:There is growing evidence that maternal cardiovascular adaptation to pregnancy has long-lasting consequences for cardiovascular health, with a paucity of information on postpartum changes. We aimed to evaluate patterns of pregnancy-induced uterine vascular changes postpartum in a rat model.METHODS:The uterine vasculature of adult Sprague Dawley rats (n=24) was examined 1 and 4 weeks postpartum (1PP, 4PP) and compared to late-pregnant (day 21, LP) and age-matched non-pregnant (NP) animals. Parameters of interest were: unstressed axial length, lumen diameter and wall thickness of the main uterine artery and vein (MUA, MUV) and proximal radial arteries (RA). Segmental artery (SA) length was also measured. Passive distensibility of RA was determined as a function of transmural pressure with pressure myography. Cross-sections of MUA stained to highlight collagen and elastin were imaged under light microscopy. Groups were compared by one-way ANOVA with tests for multiple comparisons, with significance at p<.05. Data are expressed as mean± SE. RESULTS: MUA and SA length were significantly increased in LP, with vessels remaining significantly elongated at 1PP and 4PP. MUA diameter was increased in LP and remained enlarged at 1PP (p=.002), but regressed toward NP size at 4PP. There were no changes in wall thickness during or after pregnancy. The diameter of the MUV increased significantly in LP (p<.001), but regressed to NP size by 1PP. Passive distensibility decreased progressively during pregnancy and postpartum, with significant differences between NP and 4PP at all intraluminal pressures. The collagen:elastin ratio in MUA remained unchanged from NP through LP and 1PP, but increased significantly at 4PP. CONCLUSIONS: Some vascular adaptations incurred during pregnancy persist; even amplify, while others regress. Arterial compliance, as measured by distensibility, appears to increase postpartum through mechanisms that are not known. These lingering vascular changes warrant additional investigation.Sexually Dimorphic Expression of AM and IMD in PlacentalVilli and Effect of GDM on Their Expression. TABREF224.text: Role of Placental Pathology in Unexpected Postpartum NICUAdmissions. Mark A Clapp, 1 Jad Bsat, 1 Theonia Boyd, 2 Sarah E Little, 1 Julian N Robinson. 1 1 Obstetrics,Brigham & Women's Hospital, Boston,  MA, USA; 2 Pathology, Brigham & Women's Hospital, Boston, MA, USA.   INTRODUCTION: The objective for this study was to evaluate the utility of postpartum placental review for infants admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) unexpectedly in the immediate postpartum period. METHODS: This retrospective cohort study examined all infants admitted to the NICU from a postpartum floor at a single academic hospital over five years. An experienced pathologist and maternal-fetal medicine specialist reviewed the pathology reports to determine if the findings 1) were sufficient to be related to the admission and 2) would have implications on future pregnancy management. RESULTS: There were 219 infants were admitted to the NICU. Placental pathology review was performed on 68 infants (31%). Only 5 placentas (7%) were unremarkable. The most common pathologic findings were signs of infection (chorioamnionitis or villitis, 37%), meconium (19%), infarction (18%), and thrombus (18%). The findings in 15 placentas (22%) were sufficient to account for the "rapid response" trigger indication; an additional 12 cases had findings that are typically associated with poor outcomes but could not be considered causal. On clinical review, 28 (42%) had findings that may have implications on counseling and management for future pregnancies, including ultrasounds for monitoring fetal growth (25%), thrombophiliawork-up (19%), and viral infection evaluation (6%). Postpartum placenta review for infants admitted to the NICU during the immediate postpartum period provides clinically useful information. Nearly 25% of placental findings could potentially be related to the neonatal postpartum distress, and 42% of the results may impact the management of future pregnancies.Digital Pathology Analysis Reveals an Increased Trophoblast Apoptotic Burden in Normotensive andHypertensive Fetal Growth Restriction. TABREF232.text: A Novel Technique for Ex Vivo Examination of Human PlacentalVessels. Toluwalope Junaid, 1 Robert Bradley, 2 John Aplin, 1 Edward Johnstone. 1 1 Maternal and Fetal Health Research Centre, University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom; 2 Henry Mosley X-ray Imaging Facility, University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION:In human pregnancies complicated by fetal growth restriction (FGR), the placenta exhibits vascular defects 1 . We have shown size-related branching differences in chorionic arteries and extreme hypovascularity in the periphery of FGR placentas 2 ; we hypothesize these differences involve all vascular levels. Extraction of holistic information on the placental vascular network is therefore crucial, but has been limited by inadequate methods for demonstrating placental vascular connectivity and topology. To address this, we have devised a technique to achieve a detailed account of placental vascular morphology ex vivo, and have compared placentas from normal and FGR (individualised birth ratio (IBR) ≤5 th centile) complicated pregnancies. METHODS: 3D casts of the vessel networks of normal (n=12; 6 arterial, 6 venous) and FGR (n=12; 6 arterial, 6 venous) human placentas were prepared by corrosion casting. Each cast was X-rayed in a high resolution micro-CT scanner to generate 2000 slices which were reconstructed into a single volume 3D virtual object. Vessel segmentation and measurements were done by thresholding and spatial measure protocols in Avizo® computer-aided scientific visualisation software. Data (Mean±SEM) were compared by Mann-Whitney test. RESULTS: The technique reproducibly defined vessel anatomy to 60µm resolution. As expected, placental area (PA) and weight (PW) differed significantly between the normal and FGR groups (35480±3474mm 2 vs 22861±2396mm 2 ; p=0.004 and 575.9±33.75g vs 368.7±27.36g; p=0.0006 respectively). Total vessel length was significantly shorter in FGR arterial casts (0.3±0.04mm/mm 2 vs 0.5±0.1mm/mm 2 ; p=0.03 and 15.6±1.3mm/g vs 29.9±4.6mm/g; p=0.009; adjusted for PA and PW respectively) but longer in the venous casts (1.4±0.7mm/mm 2 vs 0.3±0.05mm/mm 2 ; p=0.04 and 92±47mm/g vs 20±3mm/g; p=0.04). No significant differences were demonstrable in arterial or venous tortuosity or diameter. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates the validity of micro-CT as an effective technique for ex vivo examination of human placental vessel morphology. Our findings show impoverished vascularity in the arterial but not the venous network of FGR placentas. The effect on placental blood flow, and hence nutrient supply to the fetus, is yet unknown.1 Krebs et al 1996, AJOG 175(6):1534-42. 2 Junaid et al 2014, Placenta 35(10):808-15. TABREF234.text: Stromal Cell Derived Factor-2 (SFD2) in Human Placenta: Role inEndoplasmic Reticulum Stress. Aline R Lorenzon-Ojea, 1 Susan J Fisher, 2 Estela Bevilacqua. 1 1 Department of Cell and Developmental Biology, Institute of Biomedical Sciences -University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil; 2 Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology & Reproductive Sciences, School of Medicine, University of California, San Francisco, CA, USA.INTRODUCTION: SDF2 is expressed in human placenta; it is upregulated during cytotrophoblast differentiation and downregulated in hypoxia. The human SDF2 is similar to Arabidopsis thaliana SDF2-like protein, which is involved in ER stress response. Adverse environmental conditions lead to disruption of endoplasmic reticulum homeostasis causing accumulation of unfolded/misfolded proteins in ER and activating the Unfolded Protein Response (UPR). UPR restores ER homeostasis, but if fails, cells go into apoptosis. In this study we investigated the SDF2 role in UPR in human placenta. METHODS: Primary cell culture of villous cytotrophoblast and BeWo cells were induced to ER stress with tunicamycin. Protein concentrations of SDF2 and GRP78/BiP were evaluated by Western Blot. Gene expression of SDF2, sXBP1 and CHOP were investigated through qPCR in SDF2silenced or not BeWo cells. Apoptosis and cell survival were evaluated by caspase-3 and ATP production luminescence assay. RESULTS: SDF2 is downregulated in CTBs after 3h and 24h of tunicamycin exposure. In BeWo cells it is downregulated after 6h of treatment and it is restored after 24h. GRP78/BiP is upregulated after 3h in CTBs, while in BeWo cells it is upregulated only after 24h. sXBP1 and CHOP mRNA confirmed ER stress condition. SDF2 mRNA did not change during tunicamycin treatment. In siRNA assays, CHOP was downregulated, GRP78/BiP activation was antecipated and the relation Caspase 3/ATP production was lower in the group SDF2-/-and treated for 3 and 6h with tunicamycin.CONCLUSIONS: Downregulation of CHOP, antecipation of GRP78/BiP and lower Caspase 3/ATP production in siRNA treated cells, indicate a role of SDF2 in the control of survival/apoptosis in trophoblast ER stress response. The placenta faces several changes in environmental conditions during development which could onset the UPR. Identifying new factors and key targets of this response could open a new field of investigation for gestation diseases. *Supported by FAPESP and CNPqThe Human Placenta at 41 Weeks of Gestation Shows Evidence of Aging With Shortened Telomeres, DNA Oxidation and Changes in IGFR2, Autophagy and the mTOR. Kaushik Maiti, 1 John Aitken, 2 Roger Smith. 1 1 Mother And Babies Research Centre, Hunter Medical Research Institute, University of Newcastle, Newcastle, NSW, Australia; 2 Discipline of Biological Sciences, Faculty of Health, University of Newcastle, Callaghan, Newcastle, NSW, Australia. INTRODUCTION: Risks of unexplained intrauterine death rise exponentially late in gestation. Previous histopathological studies of placentas from patients with intrauterine death have demonstrated vesselthickening, calcification and infarction; changes associated with aging in other tissues. We hypothesised that placentas from pregnancies beyond 39 weeks of gestation would show biochemical changes consistent with aging. In this study, we have compared term and post-dated placentas.

TABREF235.text: Fetal Survival, Inflammation and Lung Maturation: Ex-VivoUterine Environment (EVE) Therapy Using Premature Lamb Model. Yuichiro Miura, 1 Masatoshi Saito, 2 Haruo Usuda, 2 Judith Rittenschober-Bohm, 1 Paranthaman S Kannan, 3 Tadashi Matsuda, 2 John P Newnham, 1 Matthew W Kemp. 1 1 School of Women's and Infants' Health, The University of Western Australia, Perth, WA, Australia; 2 Department of Perinatal Medicine, Tohoku University Graduate School of Medicine, Sendai, Miyagi, Japan; 3 Division of Pulmonary Biology, Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, Cincinnati, OH, USA. INTRODUCTION:Ex-vivo uterine environment (EVE) therapy uses an artificial placenta to provide extracorporeal gas exchange and nutrient delivery to a fetus submerged in an artificial uterus. Development of EVE therapy may allow us to treat very premature neonates without mechanical ventilation. In the present study, we analysed the efficacy and safety of our system, based on a parallelised umbilical circuit system with a low priming volume, using premature lamb model. METHODS: Ewes underwent surgical delivery at 115 d of gestation (GA; term is 148 d) to connect fetal extracorporeal life support to the umbilical vasculature in a parallel orientation (Treatment Group; n=5). Fetuses were transferred to an artificial uterus. Physiological parameters were continuously monitored; arterial blood gas and biochemistry values were serially obtained to assess wellbeing and targeted to reference range values for 2 d. Control Group animals (n=6) were surgically delivered at 117 d of GA. Fetal inflammation and surfactant proteins were analysed and compared between Treatment and Control Group using ELISA and qPCR. RESULTS: Fetal survival time in Treatment Group was 27.0 ± 15.5 h (mean ± SD), whilst physiological parameters, arterial blood gas, and blood chemistry values were mainly kept within reference range. Fetal death in the Treatment Group prior to 45 h (3/5 animals) was unpredictable. There was no significant difference (p>0.05) in white blood cell count or surfactant mRNA expression between Treatment and Control Group. No significant elevation (p>0.05) in fetal plasma TNF-α or MCP-1 protein was shown from 8 h after birth on. Significant elevation (p<0.01) in fetal lung mRNA expression of IL-6, IL-8, and MCP-2 were demonstrated in Treatment Group compared to Control Group, whereas no significant difference (p>0.05) was observed in IL-1β or TNF-α. CONCLUSIONS: In this study, limited survival of the fetus was achieved. However, EVE therapy induced limited fetal inflammation and did not promote lung maturation. These data suggest that further development of EVE therapy for extremely preterm infants is warranted.Comparison of Morbidities Associated With Previa Versus Non-Previa Placentation in Women WithPlacenta Accreta. INTRODUCTION:Our objective was to evaluate if the presence of placenta previa is associated with increased morbidity in patients with pathology-proven placenta accreta. METHODS: Retrospective cohort study of placenta accreta cases delivered at the University of California, San Diego Medical Center 1990-2014. Placental location was determined by ultrasound. Demographic characteristics and outcomes were compared between women with a placenta previa and those without a previa. Student's T-test or the Mann-Whitney U test were used for continuous variables and chi-squared analyses for categorical variables. RESULTS: 147 placenta accreta cases were identified over the study period. A placenta previa was noted prenatally in 74% of these cases. The other placental locations were anterior

TABREF236.text: Morbidities Associated With Antepartum Bleeding in Women WithPlacenta Accreta. Kate E Pettit, 1 James Sargent, 1 Jerasimos Ballas, 2 Carri R Warshak, 3 Andrew D Hull, 1 Robert Resnik, 1 Cheryl C Saenz, 1 Gladys A Ramos. 1 1 Reproductive Medicine, University of California, San Diego, CA, USA; 2 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX, USA; 3 Maternal Fetal Medicine, University of Cinncinati, Cinncinati, OH, USA. INTRODUCTION: The study objective was to evaluate if the occurrence of antepartum vaginal bleeding is associated with increased morbidity in patients with pathology-proven placenta accreta. METHODS: Retrospective cohort study of all prenatally diagnosed placenta accreta cases delivered at the University of California, San Diego Medical Center 1990-2014. Placental location was determined by prenatal ultrasound. Demographic characteristics and outcomes were compared between those women with a hospitalization for antepartum vaginal bleeding and those without. Student's T-test or the Mann-Whitney U test were used for continuous variables and chi-squared analyses for categorical variables.

TABREF241.text: Characterization of Exosomes in Plasma From Women With AIP (Abnormally Invasive Placenta). Carlos Salomon, 1 Miharu Kobayashi, 1 Sonia DaSilva-Arnold, 2 Greg E Rice, 1 Murray D Mitchell, 1 Nicholas P Illsley, 2 Abdulla Al-Khan, 2 Stacy Zamudio. 2 1 Centre for Clinical Diagnostics, University of Queensland Centre for Clinical Research, Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital, Queensland, Australia; 2 Center for Abnormal Placentation, Dept of Ob/Gyn, Hackensack University Medical Center, Hackensack, NJ, USA.INTRODUCTION: AIP occurs when there is excessive trophoblast invasion into the maternal uterus, deep into the myometrial blood vessels, and even through the uterine serosa. The primary risk factor is placenta previa in conjunction with a uterine scar. AIP is associated with major hemorrhage, often necessitates hysterectomy and there can be invasion and damage to the bladder, bowel and other structures in the abdominal cavity. The generation of placental exosomes is altered in pregnancy complications such as preeclampsia. Given the excessive invasion and therefore increased contact with maternal blood, we hypothesized that placental exosomes might be increased in AIP vs. controls (placenta previa, PP). METHODS: Plasma was obtained from women diagnosed with PP and AIP (all percreta) at 30-34 weeks of gestation (n=4/group). Exosomes were isolated by differentialand buoyant density centrifugation. Exosomal markers (CD63 and TSG101) and a placenta-specific marker (placental alkaline phosphatase; PLAP) were measured by immunoblotting. PLAP content was normalized to total exosomal protein for the placental exosome fraction. Morphology was examined using EM and size distribution by nanoparticle tracking analysis (NanoSight™). Exosomal protein content was established by mass spectrometry. The identified protein function and canonical pathways were determinedusing PANTHER and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis, respectively. RESULTS: Exosomes were identified by EM as spherical vesicles with diameters around 100 nm which were positive for the exosome markers CD63 and TSG101. Plasma exosomal protein concentration in AIP was greater than that observed in PP (0.85±0.17 vs. 0.66±0.13 mg protein/ ml; p<0.05). There was a trend towards greater total exosome number in AIP (p=0.12) and a greater fraction being of placental origin (as measured by PLAP) in AIP (1.77±0.26) vs. PP (1.00±0.34; p=0.10). MS analysis identified common and unique exosomal proteins between AIP and PP involved in cytoskeleton organization, development, immunomodulatory and cell-to-cell communication. CONCLUSIONS: Exosome concentration and content appears to differ between women with AIP and PP. This may lead to development of unique biomarkers for AIP.Whole Genome Analysis Identifies Interleukin-6 Mediated Inhibition of Interferon-Induced 15 kDa Protein (ISG15), an Auto-InflammationSuppressor Protein in Preeclamptic Cytotrophoblasts. Selcuk Tabak, 1 Nihan Semerci, 2 Asli Uyar, 3 Ozlem Guzeloglu Kayisli, 2 Seth Guller, 4 Frederick Schatz, 2 Charles Lockwood, 2 Umit A Kayisli. 2 1 Ob&Gyn, Uni of Adiyaman, Adiyaman, Turkey; 2 Ob&Gyn, Univ of South Florida Morsani College of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA; 3 Computer Eng, Okan Univ, Istanbul, Turkey; 4 Ob&Gyn, Yale Uni School of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA. INTRODUCTION:Interleukin-11 (IL-11) and IL-6 compete for binding to the gp130 receptor to mediate signaling in target cells. Although IL-11 maintains pregnancy, increased plasma and/or decidual cell IL-6 expression is associated with preeclampsia (PE) and chorioamnionitis (CAM). Expression of gp130, IL-6R and IL-11R by interstitial trophoblast suggest that decidual cell secreted IL-11/IL-6 act as paracrine factors on neighboring trophoblasts. Using whole genome analysis, this study investigated individual and combined effects of IL-11 and IL-6 on cytotrophoblast (CTB) gene expression. METHODS: Human CTBs were isolated from placenta after cesarean delivery (n=3). Microarray analysis was performed on RNA extracts from cultured CTB treated with control, or 1ng/ml of IL-11 or IL-6 or IL-11+IL-6 for 4 h using an Illumina Global Human Microarray kit. Statistical analysis focused on genes expressed at 1.5-fold over threshold. Relevant genes were confirmed by qRT-PCR and immunostaining of placental sections obtained from normal (n=6), PE (n=6) and CAM (n=7) associated pregnancies. RESULTS: In IL11-treated CTBs vs. controls, 142 genes are differentially expressed (18 up-and 124 down-regulated). In IL6-treated CTBs vs. controls, 243 genes are differentially expressed (120 up-and 123 downregulated). After incubation of CTBs with IL11+IL6 vs. IL11, 7 genes are differentially expressed (4 up-and 3 down-regulated). Among 3 downregulated genes, ISG15 was confirmed by qRT-PCR. HSCORE analysis of immunostaining revealed that compared to normal placenta, interstitial CTBs in preeclamptic placenta, but not in CAM associated placenta, express significantly lower ISG15 immunoreactivity (Mean ± SEM 139.7±11.4, 59.0±14.2 and 86.6±22.4, respectively; p<0.01). CONCLUSIONS: These results suggest that differential regulation of IL11-mediated gene expression by IL6 in CTBs promote decidual autoinflammation by inhibiting ISG15, which in turn elicits the development of inflammatory milieu in PE. Thus, compounds increasing ISG15 expression may exert therapeutic benefits by preventing inflammation in PE.Supported by McKern Award to UAKEpigenetic Regulation of Placental HSD11B2 Identifies Class-Specific HDAC and DNMT Inhibitors as Novel Protective Pharmacotherapy for the Human Placenta. Katie L Togher, 1,2 Jason Radford, 2 Louise C Kenny, 1 Gerard W O'Keeffe. 1,2 1 Irish Centre for Fetal and Neonatal Translational Research (INFANT), Cork University Maternity Hospital, Cork, Munster, Ireland; 2 Department of Anatomy & Neuroscience, University College Cork, Cork, Munster, Ireland. INTRODUCTION:Fetal overexposure to maternal cortisol has been proposed to increase the risk of low birth weight and later disease risk. Placental 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase-2 (HSD11B2) protects the fetus by inactivating cortisol. Environmental stress and infection during pregnancy is correlated with reduced HSD11B2 expression, potentially resulting in fetal overexposure to cortisol. However, this has not been directly shown and there is no preventative pharmacotherapy. METHODS: Single cell densitometry was used to quantify HSD11B2 expression in JEG-3 cells post exposure to cortisol(0-2mM), IL-1β(1-100ng/ml), DNA methyltransferase(DNMT) inhibitor Decitabine and Histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors SAHA, MC1568, MS275 and PCI (all 1-10mM). For in vivo analyses, pregnant Sprague-Dawley rats received each inhibitor (0.1-1mg/kg) intraperitoneally on E16 and placental HSD11B2 expression and fetal characteristics were examined on E18. RESULTS: Exposure to cortisol and IL-1β resulted in a dose-dependent reduction in HSD11B2 expression in JEG-3 cells. Pan and Class-specific HDAC and DNMT inhibitors resulted in a dose-dependent increase in HSD11B2 expression in vitro and protected JEG3 cells against the detrimental effects of Cortisol and IL-1β on HSD11B2 expression, and we also extended these analyses in vivo. CONCLUSIONS: We show that cortisol and IL-1β directly affect placental HSD11B2 expression, and that class-specific inhibitors of HDAC and DNMTs have potential as protective pharmacotherapy against the effects on stress and infection on the developing fetus.Oxidative Stress and Compensatory Anti-Inflammatory Mechanismsin the Placentas of Gravid Marijuana Smokers. Michelle C Tsai, Matthew Loichinger, Tricia Wright. Department of OB/GYN, University of Hawaii John A. Burns School of Medicine, Honolulu, HI, USA.INTRODUCTION: α-Klotho is a membrane-associated protein expressed in placental syncytiotrophoblast. It regulates phosphatemediated oxidative stress and may affect the function and lifespan of the placenta. Human sirtuin-1 (SIRT-1) down-regulates cytokines, matrix metalloproteinases, and prostaglandins. SIRT-1 has been well-studied in the human placenta and has been shown to confer a protective effect against oxidative stress. The aim of the study was to determine the effects of marijuana on fetal growth and investigate placental α-Klotho and SIRT-1 in gravid marijuana smokers compared to normal gestational age matched controls. METHODS: This was a prospective cohort study. The control group (N=10) included women with uncomplicated term pregnancies. Marijuana users (N=9) included term women with documented marijuana use during pregnancy without any other substance abuse, including alcohol or tobacco. Placental samples were collected immediately after delivery, formalin fixed, placed in paraffin blocks and sectioned. α-Klotho polyclonal antibody (Santa Cruz) and Vectorstain ELITE kit (Vector Labs) were used for immunocytochemistry and quantitation performed with a CRI Nuance spectral analyzer. Student's T-test was used with significance set at p<0.05.RESULTS:Patient demographics were similar between groups. Placental α-Klotho expression was not significantly different between groups (p=0.41). There was no significant difference in SIRT-1 expression in the placental vascular endothelium (p=0.3) or syncytiotrophoblast (p=0.42) between groups. Neonates born to mothers who smoked marijuana weighed significantly less (477g; 1.05lbs) than babies born to normal controls (p=0.01). *Figure(s) will be available online. CONCLUSIONS: Smoking marijuana in pregnancy did not have an effect on placental α-Klotho or SIRT-1 expression in this small cohort of patients. However, birth weights of term infants born to mothers who smoked marijuana during pregnancy were significantly less than those born to normal control mothers.Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress Is Induced in the HumanPlacenta During Labour. Jan HW Veerbeek, Martha C Tissot van Patot, Graham J Burton, Hong-Wa Yung. Department of Physiology, Development, and Neuroscience, University of Cambridge, Cambridge, Cambridgeshire, United Kingdom. Using clinically established cutoff values for postpartum cardiovascular markers, we show significantly more patients with a low HDL (20.7% vs. 48.3% p=0.026) and high homocysteine (17.2% vs. 65.5% p=<0.001) in the PE group. CONCLUSIONS: Preeclampsia is associated with lower T cell numbers and other characteristic inflammatory and vascular changes to the spiral arteries of the placental bed, resembling several features of early atherosclerosis. We hypothesize that lower T-cell presence may cause increased innate immunity activity with subsequent decreased EVT migration and abnormal SA remodelling in early stages of pregnancies destined to be complicated by PE.Increased Prohibitin-1 Expression Contributes To IncreasedOxidative Stress in Preeclamptic Placentas. Yuping Wang, Yang Gu, Lynn J Groome. Obstetrics & Gynecology, LSU Health Sciences Center, Shreveport, LA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Prohibitins (PHB1 and PHB2) are mitochondria proteins located at the inner mitochondria membrane. Although PHBs are required for optimal mitochondrial morphology and function, the precise molecular function of PHBs in the placenta is unknown. Mitochondrial dysfunction has been reported in placental trophoblasts in preeclampsia (PE). However, placental PHB expression and their function associated with oxidative stress have never been studied in PE. We hypothesis that increased PHB expression may contribute to deregulation of anti-oxidative activity in placental trophoblast cells (TCs) in PE. METHODS: PHB1 and PHB2 expression was determined by Western blot using total tissue protein and by immunostaining of paraffin embedded tissue sections in 14 placentas, 7 normal and 7 PE. To specifically study effects of PHB1 associated with oxidative stress, PHB1 siRNA was transfected into primary isolated TCs from normal placentas. TC MnSOD and CuZnSOD expression was determined by Western blot and TC oxidative stress was determined by measuring 8-isoprostane production. A probability level <0.05 was considered statistically significant. RESULTS: Relative expression of PHB1 and PHB2 was significantly increased in PE placentas compared to normal term placentas, PHB1: 1.61±0.16 vs. 0.88±0.05, p<0.05; PHB2: 1.29±0.10 vs. 0.85±0.06, p<0.05.

TABREF250.text: Pathway in the Etiopathogenesis of Preeclampsia. Aneta Dobierzewska, Macarena Palominos, Marianela Sanchez, Michael Dyhr, Horacio Figureoa, Sebastian Illanes. Dept.of Obstetrics & Gynecology, Universidad de los Andes, Santiago, Las Condes, Chile. INTRODUCTION: Preeclampsia(PE)is the major disorder of human pregnancy characterized by maternal hypertension, proteinuria, edema, and in severe cases;seizures, renal and liver failure. PE affects 5-8% of all pregnancies, causing 40% of premature births worldwide and is often associated with fetal complications, like IUGR. PE begins with inadequate trophoblast invasión early in pregnancy and reduced uteroplacental perfusión that results in maternal systemic inflammatory response.

TABREF267.text: Endometriosis is a gynecological condition in which cells of the endometrium grow outside the uterine cavity. In order to test new non-hormonal clinical candidates for the treatment of endometriosis an animal pain model mimicking one or more relevant symptoms of the disease needs to be developed.

TABREF324.text: Physicians were questioned on the last 3 pregnant pts or those planning a pregnancy on whom they had consulted. Pt survey included women with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) or inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) who had been pregnant in the past 2 years. RESULTS: 22 OBGYN and 50 DS completed the doctor survey. 57 RA and 56 IBD pts completed the pt survey. When planning pregnancy 50% of pts consulted their OBGYN and 43% their DS. On learning of pregnancy 66% of pts consulted their OBGYN and 34% their DS. For OBGYN 40% of initial visits were prior to pregnancy, with 35% in 1st trimester. For DS 68% of initial visits were prior to pregnancy. During pregnancy OBGYN saw 69% of pts once a month or more, 28% every trimester and 3% only once during pregnancy. 88% and 83% of pts reported that OBGYNs and DS respectively were very influential on how they managed their pregnancy. A treatment plan related to management of RA/IBD or pregnancy was initiated by OBGYN for 55% of pts. This was 56% for DS. 34% of OBGYNs made treatment changes in anticipation of or during pregnancy. This was 60% for rheumatologists and 27% for gastroenterologists. 82% of OBGYN collaborated with other physicians when managing pts, with disease progression and pregnancy monitoring key discussion topics. CONCLUSIONS: Although patients had a high level of interaction with both their DS and OBGYN throughout pregnancy, only about half had a treatment plan in place. The findings emphasise the importance of crosscollaborative care and sharing of information between physicians involved in the management of women with rheumatological and gastrointestinal conditions during family planning and pregnancy.

TABREF494.text: Bleeding Patterns in African American Versus Caucasian WomenTreated With Ulipristal Acetate (UPA): Secondary Data Analysis of Two Randomized Controlled Trials. Torie C Plowden, 1 Shvetha M Zarek, 1 Sunni L Mumford, 2 Lynnette K Nieman, 1 Alicia Y Armstrong. 1 1 Program in Reproductive and Adult Endocrinology, Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, NIH, Bethesda, MD, USA; 2 Division of Intramural Population Health Research, Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, NIH, Bethesda, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION:Prior studies have demonstrated that the selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM), UPA, effectively controlled bleeding and reduced fibroid volume, with African American (AA) women having a greater reduction in fibroid size. An additional benefit of this therapy is therapeutic amenorrhea without hypoestrogenic symptoms. The objective of this study was to determine if race or other demographic factors are associated with amenorrhea in women taking UPA for treatment of leiomyoma. METHODS: This study was a subgroup analysis from two prospective, randomized, placebo-controlled trials at a clinical research center. Information on dosage, age, pregnancy history, body mass index, race, bleeding, and time to amenorrhea was obtained from the medical records of women enrolled in a clinical trial of UPA. RESULTS: Fifty-one African American (AA) and thirteen non-AA premenopausal women underwent treatment with UPA at 10 mg, 20 mg, or placebo. After conclusion of treatment, no patients receiving placebo demonstrated amenorrhea compared to 73.9% receiving UPA (p<0.05). The factor that was most associated with amenorrhea was treatment with UPA (p <.0001). There was no difference in amenorrhea rates between AA and Caucasian women (p=0.75). Women with amenorrhea experienced fewer cycles with an LH surge (p=0.038). Prior to the development of amenorrhea, women who subsequently developed amenorrhea were likely to bleed for longer periods of time (p= 0.04). Demographic factors such as age, parity and BMI were not associated with amenorrhea. CONCLUSIONS: UPA treatment was the strongest predictor of amenorrhea. There were no racial differences in amenorrhea rates. All patients receiving UPA, at the study dosages, should be expected to have high rates of amenorrhea regardless of other demographic and reproductive health characteristics.Effect of GnRH Agonist on MED12 Wild Type and Mutated UterineFibroids. Helge G Roider, 1 Andrea Wagenfeld, 2 Joerg Mueller, 1 Ralf Lesche, 1 Martina Runge, 1 Alison Murray, 3 Hilary OD Critchley. 3 1 Bayer Pharma AG, Common Mechanism Research, Berlin, Germany; 2 Bayer Pharma AG, Therapeutic Research Group Oncology/Gynecological Therapies, Berlin, Germany; 3 The Queen's Medical Research Institute, University of Edinburgh, MRC Centre for Reproductive Health, Edinburgh, Scotland, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: Uterine fibroids are characterized by growth dependence on sex steroids and medical treatment that reduces menstrual bleeding and fibroid size is classically based on sex steroid depletion, for example by gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist therapy. Recently exome sequencing revealed mutations in the MED12 gene in up to the 70% of uterine fibroids. The objective of our study was to elucidate the impact of MED12 status in fibroids on gene expression profile with GnRH agonist treatment. METHODS: We collected 64 samples from 33 patients (31 matched Myometrium/ Fibroid and 2 unmatched Myometrium samples) without and 26 samples from 14 patients (12 matched Myometrium / Fibroid and 2 unmatched Myometrium samples) with GnRH treatment. Uterine biopsies were collected with ethical approval and informed consent (12/SS/0238).

TABREF496.text: An In Vitro Approach To Transduction of Human Uterine Fibroid Stem Cells By Replication Incompetent Adenovirus Serotype5.Shahinaz M Shalaby, 1,2 Aymara Mas Perucho, 1 Sara A Mohamed, 1,3 Soumia Brakta, 1 Archana Lacnaur, 1 Micheal Diamond, 1 David Curiel, 4 Ayman A Al-Hendy. 1 1Obstetrics and Gynecology, Georgia Regents University,  Augusta, GA, USA; 2 Pharmacology, Tanta University, Medical School,  Tanta, Ghharbeyya, Egypt; 3 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Mansoura  University, Medical School, Mansoura, Dakahleyya, Egypt; 4 Radiation  Oncology, Washington University Medical School, St. Louis, MO, USA.   INTRODUCTION: Uterine Fibroids (UF) are a common benign tumor of reproductive age women. For women with symptomatic fibroids, there are paucity of therapeutic options, probably limited to myomectomy. However long term outcome of myomectomy is often hampered by high rate of recurrence (up to 60%).The role of stem cells in fibroid pathogenesis is being established by our group and others. Persistence of tumor-forming stem cells might be contributing to recurrence of fibroid.We have been developing adenovirus gene therapy as a potential non-surgical treatment of fibroids. In this work, we are aiming to examine the utility of Adenovirus serotype 5 to transduce human fibroid stem cells.Our central hypothesis is that efficient transduction and subsequent elimination of fibroid tumor forming stem cells is pivotal step for complete tumor eradication and decreasing recurrence. METHODS: Samples of human leiomyomas were dissected out and minced into small pieces and incubated overnight.Afterward, samples were digested with agitation by type II collagenase to obtain singlecell suspensions. These cells were analyzedand sorted using specific stem cell markers. Isolated stem cells were grown in culture.Then we used replication incompetent Adenovirus serotype 5 expressing the B-Galactosidase as a reporter gene to transfect these stem cells. The virus load used ranged from 1 plaque forming units (PFU) per cell which represents multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 1 and scaled upto 50pfu/cell. RESULTS: Human fibroid stem cells showed expression of B-Galactosidase at (MOI) of 1,10,and 50 at a percentages of 19%,62%,and 90% respectively.This rate of transduction is comparable to that of primary fibroid tumor cells that showed transduction rates of 28%,82%,and 98% at the same MOI respectively. CONCLUSIONS: Fibroid stem cells are susceptible to transduction by Adenovirus 5. These data are promising in that Adenovirus-based gene therapy could be a novel strategy to eradicate both differentiated fibroid cells as well as tumor-forming stem cells which might improve long term tumor ablation and decrease possible recurrence. Both first and second authors contributed equally.Inhibitory Effects of Curcumin and Nanocurcumin on Human UterineLeiomyoma Xenograft Model In Vivo. Kenji Tsuiji, 1 Takashi Takeda, 2 Bin Li, 1 Mari Tadakawa, 1 Nobuo Yaegashi. 1 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Tohoku University Graduate School of Medicine, Sendai, Miyagi, Japan; Women's Health, Research Institute of Traditional Asian Medicine, Kinki University School of Medicine, Osaka-Sayama, Osaka, Japan.INTRODUCTION: Uterine leiomyomas are the most common gynecological benign tumors and greatly affect reproductive health and well-being. They are the leading cause of hysterectomy in premenopausal women. Curcumin, a well-known component of turmeric, has been reported to prevent various diseases such as cancer, diabetes and obesity.

TABREF497.text: Vania Vidimar, 1 David R Gius, 2 Jian-Jun Wei, 1,3 J Julie Kim. 1 1 Obstetrics andGynecology, Northwestern  University, Chicago, IL, USA; 2 Radiation Oncology, Northwestern  University, Chicago, IL, USA; 3  Pathology, Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA. INTRODUCTION: Uterine fibroids (leiomyomas) are benign tumors of the myometrium that occur in approximately 70% of reproductive-age women. Previously, we have shown that the AKT pathway is upregulated in leiomyoma compared to normal myometrium. In leiomyoma cells, inhibition of AKT promotes senescence and inhibits growth. However, it is unclear why AKT is overactive in leiomyomas. We hypothesize that oxidative stress caused by an intrinsic dysregulation of the redox system activates the AKT pathway and promotes survival in leiomyomas. METHODS: Primary leiomyoma (ULM) and myometrial (MM) cells isolated from tissues post surgery were used. Western Blotting, immunohistochemistry as well as biochemical and cell-based assay including WST-1, reactive oxygen species (ROS) and glutathione (GSH) quantification were performed. RESULTS: Pro-oxidative stimuli (H 2 O 2 ) increased pAKT levels in ULM cells but not in MM cells. Interestingly, while high doses of H 2 O 2 reduced ULM cell viability, viability of MM cells was not affected. MnSOD is the primary defense against oxidative stress in cells. Acetylation of MnSOD leads to accumulation of inactive MnSOD. Immunostaining of a tissue microarray containing over 100 matched leiomyoma/myometrial tissues showed that levels of acetylated MnSOD were higher in leiomyomas than in matched myometrium. Moreover, the MnSOD mimetic GC4419 reduced pAKT protein levels in ULM cells supporting our hypothesis. Inhibition of AKT with MK-2206 led to cell death in ULM cells at doses that increased superoxide levels and decreased GSH. The cytotoxic effects of MK-2206 were reversed by GC4419, suggesting that MK-2206 triggers oxidant-induced cell death of ULM cells by impairing the GSH/ ROS balance. CONCLUSIONS: Leiomyomas have an impaired oxidative system due to the aberrant acetylation of MnSOD. This oxidative environment, likely sustained by the hypoxic milieu of leiomyomas, upregulates the AKT pathway. Therefore, targeting the AKT pathway is a rational approach for fibroid therapy without affecting the myometrium.Vitamin D Elicits Anti-InflammatoryResponsein Human FemaleDetrusor Muscle Cells: Implication for Overactive Bladder Syndrome. Mohamed Abdelaziz, Noura Eziba, Muhammad Ansar, Nahed Ismail, Michael Diamond, John Lue, Barbara Robinson, Ayman Al-Hendy. OB/ GYN, GRU, Augusta, GA, USA. INTRODUCTION:

TABREF498.text: Models for Uterine Ligament Surface Receptors: Cell Culture,Explants and Immunohistochemistry. Shawna S Brizzolara, 1 Jacqueline Bunga, 2 Brittany L Sato, 2 Claire E Kendal-Wright. 2 1 OB/GYN, University of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI, USA; 2 Nat Sc and Math, Chaminade University of Honolulu, Honolulu, HI, USA. INTRODUCTION: Pelvic organ prolapse (POP) occurs when the pelvic floor no longer supports the pelvic organs, causing them to herniate. Our previous published work has shown the upregulation of TLR pathway in the Round (RL) and Uterosacral (USL) ligaments of women with POP. Therefore, our aims are 1) to develop viable ligament explant cultures for mechanistic experiments 2) to develop primary culture techniques to study receptor activation and 3) to characterize TLR expression. While we concentrated on control samples, we aim to compare POP and control ligament samples. METHODS: USL and RL were collected during hysterectomy with IRB approval. They were washed in 1x PBS and three 3 mm tissue punches were sampled: (1) placed in fixative for histology, placed into paraffin blocks, sectioned and immunohistochemistry was performed for TLR 2 (1:50 Abcam), 4 (1:50 Santa Cruz) and 6 (1:100 Santa Cruz) (2) weighed and snap frozen in liquid nitrogen, (3) placed in culture with DMEM/F-12 supplemented with 10% FBS and 1% Pen/Strep. After 24 hrs the explant tissue (3) was transferred into new media and the old media frozen for LDH detection. After 5 days explants were fixed. Ligament remnants were chopped and placed into DMEM/F12 with trypsin (2mg/ml) and collagenase A (5mg/ml) at 37°C at 200 rpm for 1 hr. The samples were filtered, centrifuged at 3,000 rpm for 5 mins and the cell pellet resuspended in media plus 10% FBS and 1% Pen/Strep. Cell linage was confirmed by vimentin (1:100, abcam) immunocytochemistry. RESULTS: We demonstrated ability to isolate and culture cells from ligaments using our novel isolation protocol. We passed these cells and demonstrated fibroblastic lineage by vimentin immunocytochemistry. We show that these cells are not robust enough to survive a freezing process, and need to be utilized for experiments upon isolation and culture. We characterized an explant model for uterine ligaments and were able to keep these in culture for five days to demonstrate their viability window by LDH activity, histological cytoarchitecture and apoptosis/necrosis analysis. Finally, we demonstrated the expression of TLR 2, 4 and 6 in both USL and RL by immunohistochemistry. CONCLUSIONS: We demonstrated the ability to collect and develop new methods to culture human ligaments for downstream assays. Therefore receptor characterization assay and functional significance studies are ongoing.Vitamin D Inhibits Interleukin-1β Induced Increase in Contractile Proteins in Primary Detrussor Smooth Muscle Cells of UrinaryBladder. Archana Laknaur, 1 Ahsen R Chaudhry, 2 Ayman Al-Hendy, 1 Chandrasekhar Thota. 2 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Georgia Regents University, Augusta, GA, USA; 2 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Meharry Medical College, Nashville, TN, USA. INTRODUCTION: African American (AA) women have lower levels of vitamin D. Similarly postmenopausal women, irrespective of the race were reported to exhibit hypovitaminosis D due to reduced synthesis of vitamin D. Both African American and postmenopausal women are known to be susceptible to infections and are reported to have a higher incidence of overactive bladder. Since Vitamin (vit)D has been reported to play an important role in innate and adaptive immunities, subclinical infection in women with low levels of vit D may increase inflammation and expression of contractile proteins in detrusor smooth muscle cells and thereby increase incidence of overactive bladder. The objective of the study is to assess if 1,25(OH)2 vit D (Vit D3) administration can decrease interleukin(IL)-1β induced increase in contractile proteins in detrussor smooth muscle cells obtained from urinary bladder of an AA woman. METHODS: Primary detrussor smooth muscle cells isolated from an AA woman's urinary bladder were obtained from Lifeline Cell Technology and cultured as suggested by the supplier. At confluence, cells were incubated in medium containing 2% fetal bovine serum for 24 h and were treated in triplicates with different concentrations of Vit D3 (1.0, 10, 100 nM) for 24 and 48h. Detrussor muscle cells were also treated in triplicates with different concentrations of IL-1β ( 0.1, 1.0 and 10.0 ng/ml). In a separate experiment cells were treated in triplicate with different concentrations of vit D3 (1.0, 10, 100 nM) in the presence of known concentration of IL-1β (10ng/ml). RNA was isolated a using Qiagen kit after 24h and protein was extracted using RIPA buffer after 48h. Real time PCR and western analysis were performed to measure cytokines and contractile proteins using appropriate primers and antibodies. RESULTS: Vit D3 treatment caused a dose dependent decrease (p<0.05) in the mRNA expression of cytokines IL-1β, IL6, IL8, TNFα, Connexin-43, cox2. Western analysis showed a decrease (P<0.05) in Connexin-43 and cox2 expression. Vit D3 decreased (p<0.05) IL-1β induced increase (p<0.05) in connexin-43 and cox2 expression. CONCLUSIONS: These results suggest that vit D3 reduces proinflammatory cytokines and contractile proteins and inhibits IL-1β induced increase in contractile proteins in detrussor smooth muscle cells of urinary bladder.Secondary Vestibulodynia Is Associated With IL-4 PromoterVariant in Caucasian Women. Joshua Miles, 1 Martha Monson, 2 Jessica Hebert, 1 Mayu Morita, 1 Terry Morgan. 1 1 Ob/Gyn and Pathology, OHSU, Portland, OR, USA; 2 Obstetrics & Gynecology, University of Utah, SLC, UT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Provoked localized vulvodynia(PLV, vestibulodynia)   affects approximately 10% of women. It is the leading cause of painful sex and the cause is unknown. We have shown there is significant neurogenic inflammation in vestibular biopsies from these patients compared with carefully matched unaffected controls. This tissue pathology is very similar to interstital cystitis (painful bladder), which occurs in about 20% of PLV patients. Although PLV is not currently considered to be a genetic disease, numerous studies suggest interstital cystitis has genetic risk factors, including an association with an IL-4 promoter variant that predisposes patients to hypersensitivity reactions. We hypothesized this IL-4 variant will be associated with PLV. METHODS: Retrospective analysis of 512 DNA samples from 271 white unaffected negative controls (no history of PLV, or family history), 119 primary PLV cases, and 122 secondary cases diagnosed in our Program of Vulvar Health by gynecologists with more than 14 years of experience with this disease. Women with primary PLV had experienced pain at the first introital touch; whereas, women with secondary PLV experienced pain only after a prior period of pain-free intercourse. Clinical charts were reviewed to screen for a history of interstitial cystitis and allergies.
