INTRODUCTION:Early first sexual intercourse (FSI) is a risk factor for unplanned teenage pregnancy, sexually transmitted infection and adverse social, emotional and physical health outcomes in adolescence and into adulthood. The aim of this study was to examine relationships between internalizing (e.g. anxious/depressed, withdrawn) and externalizing (e.g. delinquent, aggressive) behavior problems in childhood and age at FSI. METHODS: We utilized a large, population-based birth cohort (The Western Australian Pregnancy Cohort (Raine) Study) to address this question. Child behavior was measured using the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL) collected from parents at ages 2, 5, 8, 10 and 14 and scores calculated for total, internalizing and externalizing behavior problems. At age 17, 1,200 participants reported sexual behavior. RESULTS: Participants with clinically significant CBCL scores (T≥60)

TABREF501.text: Evaluation of the Diagnostic Accuracy of Cervical Biopsy and the Determination of Margin Status and Associated Risk Factors forRecurrent Cervical Dysplasia After LEEP or Conization. Diana P English, Monica Pasternak, Sudeshna Chatterjee, Dan-Arin Silasi, Masoud Azodi, Alessandro Santin, Thomas Rutherford, Peter Schwartz, Elena Ratner. Obstetrics and Gynecology, Division of Gynecologic Oncology, Yale University School of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA. INTRODUCTION:To determine the prevalence and associated risk factors for positive surgical margins on cold knife conization or LEEP as well as the recurrence of dysplasia after these procedures. Secondary objective was to determine the correlation of cervical biopsy revealing CIN II with degree of dysplasia found on final pathology after definitive excisional procedure. Pregnancy outcome data on eligible patients was also collected. METHODS: This is a retrospective study of 135 patients who underwent a LEEP or cone biopsy during a 12 year period (1999-2011) by trained gynecologic oncologists. Medical records were reviewed from a prospectively maintained database. Cases were identified through a search performed for all patients with a CIN II diagnosis. All pathology specimens were reviewed by one of four board specialized gynecologic pathologists. The need for cervical biopsy was determined based on pap smear results according to the standard ASCCP guidelines. Women under 49 years were linked to birth registry data. Univariate analysis performed with chi-square and Student's t-test. RESULTS: Of the 135 patients, 35 cases had a positive cone/LEEP margin (25.9%)

TABREF502.text: Treatment Failure of Bacterial Vaginosis After Metronidazole Therapy Is Not Associated With Changes in Cervicovaginal Fluid Proteome. Camila Marconi, 1 Carolina ST Ferreira, 1 Pontes G Leticia, 2 Santos D Lucilene, 2 Silva G Marcia. 1 1 Pathology, Botucatu Medical School, Univ Estadual Paulista, UNESP, Botucatu, Sao Paulo, Brazil; 2 Center for Studies of Venoms and Venomous Animals, CEVAP, Univ Estadual Paulista, UNESP, Botucatu, Sao Paulo, Brazil. INTRODUCTION: Bacterial vaginosis(BV)is the most common type of abnormal vaginal flora. Treatment of BV is performed with metronidazole and remains a challenge at clinical practice. Cervicovaginal fluid proteomic profile in BV has been evaluated in a few studies, however how it is related with the response to treatment of this condition has not been elucidated so far. Thus, we aimed to characterize the cervicovaginal proteome of women with BV in relation to normal flora and to compare the proteomic profile between those women who were successfully treated with women who failed to reestablish lactobacillar flora after 7-days metronidazole regimen METHODS: We cross-sectionally enrolled 150 women, but 15 had to be excluded because they tested positive for Chlamydia trachomatis and/or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Vaginal flora was classified according to Nugent's criteria and showed that 38 women had bacterial vaginosis, 15 intermediate and 82 normal flora. Cervicovaginal samples of the 38 women with BV and 38 randomly selected women with normal flora were evaluated by shotgun LC-MS/MS (Q-Tof Ultima, MicroMass/Waters).

TABREF503.text: Alpha Amylase Levels in Vaginal Fluid and Its Relation To Anti-Bacterial and Membrane Degradation Mediators. DimitriosNasioudis, 1 Joziani Beghini, 1,2 Ann Marie Bongiovanni, 1 Paulo C Giraldo, 2 Iara M Linhares, 3 Steven S Witkin. 1 1 Department ofObstetrics  and Gynecology, Weill Cornell Medical College, New York, NY, USA;  2 Department of Gynecology and Obstetrics, University of Campinas,  Campinas, Sao Paulo, Brazil; 3 Department of Gynecology and Obstetrics,  University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil.   INTRODUCTION: The vaginal pH is 3.8-4.5 due to lactic acidproducing bacteria, primarily Lactobacilli. Vaginal glycogen is degraded by host-derived alpha amylase and converted to lactic acid by bacteria. In women with bacterial vaginosis (BV) Lactobacilli are replaced by anaerobic and facultative microbes and the vaginal pH is elevated. Conversely, the vaginal microbiota and vaginal pH remains unaltered in women with vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC). Since alpha amylase is the substrate for Lactobacilli we evaluated whether its concentration was altered in vaginal fluid from women with BV and VVC and its associations with vaginal lactic acid and host mediators.Underutilization of Metabolic Screening Studies in Patients WithPolycystic Ovary Syndrome. Amy S Dhesi, 1 Jonathan K Lim, 1 Amy Solnica, 1 Peter G McGovern. 1,2 1 Obstetrics & Gynecology, Rutgers -New Jersey Medical School, Newark, NJ, USA; 2 Obstetrics & Gynecology, Mount Sinai St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital, New York, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION: Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) have an increased risk for metabolic abnormalities including glucose intolerance, diabetes mellitus, and dyslipidemia. In 2002, the American College of Obstetrics & Gynecology (ACOG) published recommendationsthat all patients with PCOS should undergo a 2-hour glucose tolerance test (GTT) and lipid profile. Our primary objective was to identify the number of patients with a diagnosis of PCOS that have undergone this screening by their referring physician. METHODS: An IRB-approved retrospective chart review was performed on 157 patients (age 18-50 years) referred to our university-affiliated reproductive endocrinology and infertility practice between January 2010 and December 2012 with a diagnosis of PCOS based on Rotterdam criteria. Data collected comprised of age at time of initial consultation, criteria for diagnosis of PCOS, referring physician specialty, medical history, physical exam findings, and laboratory values including 2-hour GTT and fasting lipid profile. Chi-square analysis and logistic regression were performed using SigmaPlot 11.0, Systat Software, Inc, San Jose, CA; p<0.05 was considered significant. RESULTS: Patients were referred by general gynecologists (n=105), outside reproductive endocrinologists (n=25), primary care physicians (n=19), medical endocrinologists (n=7), and unknown providers (n=23). Prior to initial consultation in our clinic, only 9.3% of patients had a 2-hour GTT and 23.6% had a lipid profile performed. Among those who had the above testing done prior to or after initial consultation, we found that patients were more likely to be tested for dyslipidemia based on higher body mass index (BMI) [p=0.02] and based on race/ethnicity, particularly in Hispanic women [p=0.003]. BMI, race/ethnicity, and family history of diabetes did not appear to contribute to likelihood of testing for glucose intolerance [p>0.05]. CONCLUSIONS: This is the first study to demonstrate that the vast majority of patients diagnosed with PCOS are not undergoing the appropriate screening tests for glucose intolerance and dyslipidemia, despite current ACOG recommendations. Routine practices of providers caring for PCOS patients must be explored to determine the obstacles in obtaining appropriate metabolic screening in this high risk population.

TABREF504.text: Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) -Evidence of Mononuclear Cell (MNC) Preactivation. Frank Gonzalez, Robert V Considine, Sarah L Pardue, Anthony J Acton. Obstetrics and Gynecology and 2 Medicine, Indiana University School of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA. INTRODUCTION: In PCOS, MNC exhibit increased sensitivity to saturated fat ingestion. This triggers inflammation potentiated in obese individuals by a concomitant rise in circulating lipopolysaccharide (LPS).We evaluated the status of plasma LPS and TLR-2, TLR-4 and SOC-3 protein content from MNC in the fasting state in women with PCOS compared with ovulatory controls; and their relation to insulin sensitivity and the ovarian androgen response to HCG administration. METHODS: We studied 16 women with PCOS (8 lean, 8 obese) between ages 18-40, diagnosed on the basis of oligomenorrhea and hyperandrogenemia, and 16 ovulatory controls (8 lean, 8 obese) of similar age. Plasma LPS was measured by fluorescence and TLR-2, TLR-4 and SOC-3 protein content were quantified by Western blotting in MNC isolated from fasting blood samples within 5-8 days of menses. Insulin sensitivity was derived by IS OGTT . Androgens were measured from blood samples drawn at 0, 24, 48 and 96 hours after administration of a 5000 IU IM HCG injection. RESULTS: Fasting LPS was similar in all 4 groups. Compared with lean controls, lean and obese women with PCOS and obese controls exhibited greater TLR-2 (4.1±0.7 vs. 7.8±1.4, 8.8±0.8, 6.7±1.1, p<0.02), TLR-4 (6.7±0.7 vs. 8.7±0.7, 9.6±0.5, 8.8±0.9, p<0.05) and SOCS-3 (4.2±0.5 vs. 7.5±0.8, 7.6±0.9, 6.4±1.0, p<0.02). Compared with weight-matched controls, women with PCOS exhibited greater area under the curve (AUC) following HCG administration for testosterone (T) (lean: 6351±849 vs. 4010±340, p<0.05; obese: 7076±1236 vs. 3728±226, p<0.006), and androstenedione (A) (lean: 472±26 vs. 317±26, p<0.0008; obese: 511±15 vs. 315±42, p<0.0001). IS OGTT was negatively correlated with TLR-2 In PCOS, TLR-2, TLR-4 and SOCS-3 are increased in the fasting state independent of obesity, and may account for increased MNC sensitivity to saturated fat ingestion. This phenomenon may promote insulin resistance and atherogenesis, the latter of which may be perpetuated by hyperandrogenism.Increased Rate of Oocyte Loss in PCOS Patients Corresponds ToDiminished Fecundity Compared To Non-PCOS Patients. Creighton E Likes III, Rebecca C Crowe, Bruce A Lessey, David A Forstein, Paul B Miller, William E Roudebush. Obstetrics & Gynecology, Greenville Health System, Greenville, SC, USA. INTRODUCTION:Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) production by ovarian granulosa cells during the reproductive years are representative of the ovarian reserve. AMH is significantly higher in women with Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS). The study objective examined the association between AMH, age, and pregnancy potential in women with and without PCOS. METHODS: AMH levels, diagnoses, and demographics was analyzed between groups of low (<1), normal (1-4), and high (>4) AMH levels, groups of women ages 20-29, 30-34, and over 35 years of age, as well as groups of women with and without PCOS (Rotterdam criteria). Monitored cycles were compared between groups with the primary outcome being successful pregnancy. RESULTS: A total of 173 patients were included: 64, PCOS and 109, controls. AMH over time confirms higher levels in PCOS patients as compared to controls. *Figure(s) will be available online. Linear regression showed a faster rate of AMH decline, and thus ovarian reserve, in women with PCOS compared to controls. Overall pregnancy rate was 42% for both PCOS and control, and was broken down to examine rates within different age groups For ages 20-29, 54.8% of PCOS patients had successful outcomes compared to controls (48.6%). For ages 30-34, 39.1% of PCOS patients had successful outcomes compared to controls (52.5%). For women over 35, 10.0% of PCOS patients had successful outcomes compared to controls (23.5%). CONCLUSIONS: Higher AMH levels in women with PCOS contribute to a greater pregnancy potential in younger patients. However, as the PCOS patient ages, the rate of egg loss, measured by decreasing AMH, is greater than that of patients without PCOS. This increased rate of egg loss results in decreased fecundity in the older PCOS group when compared to older non-PCOS patients.Differential MicroRNA Regulation in PCOS ThecaCells. Bhavi Modi, 1 Kellie Archer, 2 Jan McAllister, 3 Jerome Strauss. 1,4 1 Human & Molecular Genetics, Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU), Richmond, VA, USA; 2 Biostatistics, VCU, Richmond, VA, USA; 3 Pathology, Penn State College of Medicine, Hershey, PA, USA; 4 Obstetrics & Gynecology, VCU, Richmond, VA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a multisystem disorder with a complex pathophysiology. Hyperandrogenemia of ovarian theca cell origin is a consistent feature of PCOS. MicroRNAs (miRs) are small, non-coding RNA molecules involved in post-transcriptional gene regulation. There is evidence for differential miR expression in the ovarian stroma, follicular fluid and granulosa cells of normal cycling andSaturday Posterswomen with PCOS. However, miR expression and target gene analyses in normal and PCOS theca cells is lacking. PCOS theca cells display differentially expressed mRNAs, which could be explained, in part by miR regulation. Understanding gene expression and its regulation in theca cells may represent a key to understanding the hyperandrogenemia associated with PCOS. METHODS: MicroRNA deep sequencing studies (Study 1: n=16; Study 2: n=8 samples) were performed on total RNA isolated from cultured normal (C: Control) and PCOS (D: Diseased) theca cells treated with (T) and without (U) 20 µM forskolin. To identify miRs differentially expressed across several group comparisons an ANOVA model was fit to the log 2 normalized expression levels, for each study and each miR. Meta-analysis was used to obtain a combined p-value of both studies. Identification of target mRNAs and pathway analysis was performed using the Ingenuity Pathway Analysis tool. RESULTS: A total of 5,936 miRs were identified in theca cells. The numbers of miRs differentially expressed for each comparison (metaanalysis FDR < 0.05) are T vs U (44); CU vs CT (31); DU vs DT (11); CT vs DT (39) and CU vs DU (79). Ten differentially expressed miRs were identified to be common between CT vs DT and CU vs DU groups (hsa-miRs: -100, -125a,

TABREF505.text: Testicular Spermatozoa Have Less DNA Damage Compared To Epidydimal Spermatozoa in Baboons. Gihan M Bareh, RandalRobinson, Ethan Jacoby, Peter Binkley, Peter Nathanielsz, Robert Schenken. Reproductive Endocrinology and Infertility, University of Texas Health Science Center, San Antonio, TX, USA. INTRODUCTION: Since the advent of intracytoplasmic sperm injection in 1992, sperm retrieval procedures have been routinely employed to treat male infertility. The anatomical location of harvested sperm (testicle or epididymis) might influence sperm DNA integrity and reproductive outcomes. Our objective was to compare sperm DNA damage in epidydimal sperm with testicular sperm METHODS: Prospective cohort animal study. This was an IRB and IACUC exempt protocol. Testicular and epidydimal tissues of 6 baboons were collected at time of necropsy. Testicular tissue was fixed and embedded in paraffin blocks sectioned for further evaluation. Epididymal flushing was used to collect epidydimal spermatozoa and smears were prepared and fixed. DNA fragmentation of the sperm from both tissue sources was assessed with terminal deoxynucleotidyltransferase dUTP nick end labeling (TUNEL). Slides were analyzed with confocal microscopy. The percentage of DNA damage was calculated using computerized software and results are expressed as mean +/-standard deviation. P value was considered significant when <0.05. RESULTS: No statistically significant difference in age was noted among all baboons (P>0.5).Testicular sperm was observed to have significantly lower rates of DNA damage compared to epididymal sperm (RR 0.26; CI 0.076-0.60; P< 0.001). *Figure(s) will be available online. CONCLUSIONS: Testicular spermatozoa have less DNA damage compared to epididymal sperm collected on the same day. Thus the anatomical location of sperm extraction may affect reproductive outcome and should be discussed when counseling patients.Obese Men With Asthenozoospermia Have Increased Sperm MotilityWith Neutral Endopeptidase (NEP) Inhibition. Jayme S Bosler, 1,4 Shibo Fu, 2 Ilir Agalliu, 3,2 Sangita Jindal, 4 Kelvin P Davies, 2 Genevieve S Neal-Perry.1,4 1 Obstetrics, Gynecology and Women's Health, Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Montefiore Medical Center, Bronx, NY, USA; 2 Urology, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, USA; 3 Epidemiology and Population Health, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, USA; 4 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Montefiore's Institute for Reproductive Medicine and Health, Hartsdale, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION:Neutral endopeptidase (NEP) is hypothesized to reduce human sperm motility through mechanisms that affect proteolysis of seminal peptides. Synthetic NEP inhibitors increase sperm motility when added to semen. We have shown both NEP and opiorphin, a potent endogenous NEP inhibitor, are abundant in seminal plasma. Although opiorphin is found in semen, it's relevance in seminal plasma and sperm, is unknown. Interestingly, blood plasma NEP activity increases with metabolic syndrome and increased BMI. We hypothesize that obese men with idiopathic asthenozoospermia have increased NEP activity and exogenous opiorphin will increase their sperm motility compared to non-obese men. METHODS: Semen samples from 55 men presenting to the Montefiore's Institute of Reproductive Medicine and Health for routine semen analysis were assessed for motility before and after the addition of 200µM of opiorphin. Men with azoospermia were excluded from the analysis. Samples were incubated at 37 o C for at least 30 minutes prior to analysis for liquefaction. Motility and forward progression were immediately assessed in triplicate and per World Health Organization (WHO) 2010 guidelines.

TABREF507.text: Adult Males With Fanconi Anemia and Dyskeratosis Congenita But Not Diamond Blackfan Anemia Have Reduced Levels of CirculatingAnti-Müllerian Hormone. P Stratton, 1 N Giri, 2 M M Sklavos, 3 B P Alter, 2 S Savage, 2 L A Pinto. 3 1 PRAE,NICHD, NIH, Bethesda, MD, USA; 2 CGB,  DCEG, NCI, NIH, Bethesda, MD, USA; 3 Leidos Biomedical Research,  FNLCR, Frederick, MD, USA.   INTRODUCTION: Fanconi anemia (FA), dyskeratosis congenita (DC) and Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA) are inherited bone marrow failure syndromes (IBMFS) associated with high risks of bone marrow failure, leukemia and solid tumors. Anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) levels are significantly reduced in reproductive-aged females with FA and DC. AMH levels may also be reduced in males with IBMFS. METHODS: Serum AMH levels were measured in post-pubertal males with FA (n=9; age 16-37 yr), DC (n=21; 15-46 yr), and DBA (n=14; 16-58 yr) within the well-characterized NCI cohort of IBMFS and two age-matched male control groups: unaffected relatives (FA=14, 14-38 yr; DC=18, 16-48 yr; DBA=11, 31-62 yr) and healthy, unrelated volunteers (n=20, 18-47 yr). AMH levels were compared between case and control groups using Mann-Whitney and Kruskal-Wallis tests; p<0.05 was significant. RESULTS: Males with FA had lower AMH levels (median=5 ng/ml, BMT) 7 to 13 years prior to AMH measurement, and 1 had head/neck cancer at study. There was no difference in AMH levels in FA patients with or without hypogonadism, or with or without BMT. Males with DC had lower AMH levels (3.9, 0-8.9) compared with relatives (5.3, 1.2-17.8, p<0.04) or unrelated controls (p<0.001). All 6 married DC patients had children, 1 with hypogonadism had AMH of 0 ng/ml, and 2 patients who previously had cancer were cancer-free at study. Eight DC patients had 1 or more manifestations of severe clinical disease (mucocutaneous triad of nail dystrophy/oral leukoplakia/reticulated skin pigmentation (n=8), severe bone marrow failure

TABREF508.text: Breast Cancer: The Impact of Chemotherapy. Jennifer L Marino, 1 Christobel M Saunders, 2,3 Laura I Emery, 2 Helena Green, 3 Dorota A Doherty, 4 Martha Hickey. 1 1 Obstetrics & Gynaecology, Univ. Melbourne, Melbourne, Australia; 2 Surgery, Univ. Western Australia, Perth, Australia; 3 Menopause Symptoms after Cancer Clinic, King Edward Memorial Hosp., Perth, Australia; 4 Women's and Infants' Health, Univ. Western Australia, Perth, Australia. INTRODUCTION: Most breast cancer patients are treated with adjuvant systemic therapy, often including chemotherapy.In younger women, chemotherapy for breast cancer may induce temporary amenorrhoea or permanent ovarian failure. For those making treatment decisions more information is needed about the potential impact of chemotherapy on vasomotor symptoms, sexual function and quality of life. The aim of this study was to compare these outcomes using validated instruments in a large clinic population of breast cancer survivors treated with adjuvant chemotherapy, compared to breast cancer survivors who had not received chemotherapy and also with women with no cancer history, controlled for current age, age at menopause, and current endocrine therapy. METHODS: Menopause clinic with dedicated service for breast cancer survivors based at a large tertiary women's hospital. Details of cancer treatment including adjuvant chemotherapy were recorded from medical records. Menopause symptoms were recorded with the Greene Climacteric Scale and the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy (FACT) -Breast Cancer (BC) and Endocrine Symptom (ES) Scales. Sexual symptoms were recorded using Fallowfield's Sexual Activity Questionnaire. Quality of life was measured with the FACT-BC, FACT-ES and FACT Social/Family Well-Being, Physical Well-Being, and Functional Well-Being subscales. RESULTS: The severity of vasomotor, psychological or sexual symptoms did not differ between breast cancer survivors who had received adjuvant chemotherapy (n=339) and other breast cancer survivors (n=465). However, severe pain with sexual intercourse was twice as common after chemotherapy (aOR 2.18, 95% CI 1.25-3.79) as among other breast cancer survivors. Vasomotor symptoms were more frequent (aOR 4.17, 95% CI 1.71-10.14) and severe (aOR 2.35, 95% CI 1.29-4.27) in breast cancer survivors compared to women without a cancer history. CONCLUSIONS: In this large study chemotherapy did not impact on nature or severity of vasomotor or psychological symptoms or quality of life. Pain with intercourse was more common in those treated with adjuvant chemotherapy. Vasomotor symptoms were more severe in breast cancer patients compared to the non-cancer clinic population.Menopausal Symptoms in Younger Women (≤40 Years) WithBreast Cancer. Michelle Peate, 1 Bettina Meiser, 2 Michael Friedlander, 2 Australian Fertility Decision Aid Collaborative Group, 2 Martha Hickey. 1 1 Obstetrics and Gynaecology, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, Australia; 2 Prince of Wales Clinical School, University of NSW, Kensington, NSW, Australia. INTRODUCTION:With 5 year survival at >89% in young women diagnosed with early breast cancer (BC), the impact of treatment on quality of life (QoL) is of growing importance. Around 80% of patients experience menopausal symptoms, and these may have substantial negative impact on their QoL. Little is known about the nature and severity of menopausal symptoms in BC patients diagnosed ≤40 years. Understanding the experience of this group is crucial for appropriate health care and followup. We report the nature and severity of menopausal symptoms and sexual function in a community based sample of 93 women ≤40 years diagnosed with early BC one year post-diagnosis following definitive BC treatment. METHODS: Recruited through 19 Australian oncology clinics, the Greene Climacteric Scale (psychological, somatic, vasomotor, and sexual interest domains) was used to measure menopausal symptoms.Higher scores indicate of more symptoms. Mean (m) domain scores were compared to women in the general population (various age groups), women attending a menopause clinic and women diagnosed with BC aged ≤64years, reported in the literature. Predictors of menopausal symptoms were explored. RESULTS: Compared to premenopausal women (m age =48.2), young BC patients (m age =33) had significantly more psychological (m=8.9 vs 5.7,p<.05) and vasomotor (m=1.8 vs 1.2,p<.05) and less sexual interest (m=1.2 vs 0.7,p<.05) symptoms. Sexual interest was also lower in young BC patients compared with women in the menopause transition (m age =50 years, <12 irregular menstruations in a year;m=1.2 vs 0.8,p<.05). Compared to women aged 40-50 years, young BC patients described more severe psychological symptoms (m=8.9 vs 7.4,p<.05), similar to those in women aged 50-64 years (m=8.9 vs 7.8,p<.05). In young BC patients, receiving combined adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy and endocrine therapy) was significantly associated with less interest in sex (F(1,91)=7.819,p=.0006). CONCLUSIONS: Young women with BC continue to experience vasomotor symptoms 12 months post-diagnosis, similar to women in spontaneous menopause transition but sexual interest is lower, particularly in those who have had both chemotherapy and endocrine therapy. Sexual dysfunction is a priority area for young BC patients and impacts negatively on QoL. This area should be addressed routinely in clinical follow-up.Comparison of Vitrified VersusFresh Donor Oocytes. Sara E Arian, 1 Jason Griffith, 2 Craig Witz, 2 Wei Wong. 2 1 The Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology, and Reproductive Scienes, The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston, TX, USA; 2 Deparment of Reproductive Sciences, Houston Fertility Institute, Houston, TX, USA. INTRODUCTION: In 2012, the American Society for Reproductive

TABREF510.text: Fertility Preservation in the LutealPhase. Christina E Boots, Melanie Meister, Amber R Cooper, Angela Hardi, Emily S Jungheim. Obstetrics & Gynecology, Division of Reproductive Endocrinology & Infertility, Washington University, St. Louis, MO, USA. INTRODUCTION:Controlled ovarian stimulation (COS) traditionally has been started in the early follicular phase. COS initiated in the luteal phase has been proposed as a mechanism to expedite fertility preservation for women with cancer. Unfortunately, existing studies comparing outcomes of COS cycles initiated in the luteal phase to those of cycles initiated in the follicular phase are small and underpowered. Our objective was to estimate differences between these two strategies to better inform future care for women undergoing fertility preservation. METHODS: A systematic search was performed in Medline, EMBASE, Scopus, CENTRAL, Clinicaltrials.gov, Cochrane library, and Google Scholar through October of 2013.

TABREF511.text: Sleep Disturbances in IVF and Fertility Preservation PatientsAre Comparable To Other Chronic Diseases But Do Not Correlate With IVF Outcomes. Brianna MW Lyttle, 1 Angela K Lawson, 2 Susan Klock, 3 Kristin Smith, 2 Ralph Kazer, 2 Jennifer Hirshfeld-Cytron, 2 Mary Ellen Pavone. 2 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of Massachusetts, Worcester, MA, Canada; 2 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Northwestern Feinberg School of Medicine, Chicago, IL, USA; 3 Fertility Centers of Illinois, , Chicago, IL, USA. INTRODUCTION:Sleep disturbance is linked to stress and negative outcomes in chronic illnesses. Infertile patients are under significant stress and report sleep disturbances, but effects of sleep problems on IVF outcomes have not yet been studied. This is a pilot study to assess sleep patterns and medical outcomes in infertile compared to fertility preservation (FP) patients with a concurrent cancer diagnosis undergoing IVF. METHODS: 55 IVF and 32 FP patients completed a pre-IVF treatment sleep questionnaire(T1) of which 50 IVF and 32 FP patients also completed a post-treatment questionnaire at the time of retrieval(T2). Medical and stimulation information were collected. Sleep disturbance, medical diagnoses and IVF stimulation results were analyzed using Spearman correlations. RESULTS: At T1, FP patients had more sleep disturbance than IVF patients (p.<001). Between T1 and T2, IVF patients' sleep disturbance significantly increased (p<.009) but FP patients' sleep disturbance did not (p=.206). For both IVF and FP patients, no correlations were found between sleep disturbance and AMH at T1. At T2, no correlations were found between sleep disturbance and peak estradiol, total medication received, number of oocytes retrieved and number of oocytes frozen. CONCLUSIONS: Sleep scores for IVF patients significantly increased between T1 and T2, often reaching values equivalent to national levels cited for chronic illnesses. However, sleep disturbance did not correlate with total medication received, peak estradiol, or treatment-related outcomes. This suggests medications leading to alterations in hormone levels do not increase sleep disturbance. The increase in sleep disturbance between T1 and T2 in IVF patients may reflect the stress ART has on patients undergoing treatment.Reproductive Health DecisionsFollowing Breast Cancer Diagnosis. Kimberly K Ma, 1 Vijayakrishna K Gadi, 2 Courtney J Preusse, 2 Christopher I Li, 2 Jean A McDougall, 2 David Mahoney, 2 Hilary S Gammill. 1 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Univ. of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA; 2 Clinical Research, Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, Seattle, WA, USA.INTRODUCTION: Young women with breast cancer are often faced with opposing choices regarding preserving fertility and fulfilling childbearing desires when treating their malignancies. Decisions regarding reproductive choices vary considerably. We sought to ascertain utilization rates of oncofertility treatment in this population and hypothesized that parity at the time of cancer diagnosis would predict reproductive choices.RESULTS:Expression of both Ang II receptor was significantly high in dominant follicle and the distinction degree was larger in Ang II R-I compared to those of Ang II R-II between dominant and atresia in vitro matured mouse follicles. CONCLUSIONS: During in vitro maturation of mouse follicle, expression of Ang II receptor was related with selection of dominant follicle. This finding suggest that Ang II might be related to mechanism of dominant follicle selection during folliculogenesis (2013R1A1A2064077).Advanced Glycation End-Products and Vitamin D: Link BetweenDiet and PCOS? Zaher Merhi, 1 Frederick Naftolin, 1 Ahmed Fadiel, 1 Kendall Krebs, 2 Marilyn Cipolla. 2 1 Obstetrics and Gynecology, NYU Langone Medical Center, New York, NY, USA; 2 Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of Vermont College of Medicine, Burlington, VT, USA. INTRODUCTION:Women with PCOS commonly have elevated levels of the pro-inflammatory advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) and low levels of vitamin D (VD). AGEs are highly reactive molecules that form when lipids or proteins become glycated after exposure to glucose. AGEs accumulate in the serum and ovaries of women with PCOS potentially altering ovarian function. Additionally, a high-AGE diet (like today's fast food) fed to animals induces metabolic and hormonal disturbances similar to those observed in PCOS. We have recently shown that VD induces a state of luteinization in human cumulus granulosa cells (GCs). We thus hypothesized that AGEs induce abnormal steroidogenesis and follicular development and that VD attenuates the AGE-induced ovarian dysfunction. METHODS: Experiment #1: Six women who underwent oocyte retrieval for IVF were enrolled. GCs were cultured in media (control) ± human glycated albumin (HGA) as a source of AGEs (0.2-0.4 mg/mL) ± 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 (VD3; 50-100 nM) for 48 h after which mRNA was compared using RT-PCR for LHR, AMH and its receptor (AMHR-II), RAGE (pro-inflammatory membranous receptor for AGEs), and VD receptor (VDR). Experiment #2: The effect of AGEs in the presence or absence of VD3 on RAGE protein was assessed by immunofluorescence. GCs from 4 participants were treated with media (control) or HGA (0.4 mg/mL) ± VD3 (100 nM) for 48 h. Data were expressed as % change or median (range). RESULTS: Compared to controls, HGA significantly increased LHR (59%) and AMHR-II (52%) mRNA levels (p<0.05) but did not alter AMH or VDR mRNA levels. The addition of VD3 inhibited the HGA-induced upregulation in LHR and AMHR-II mRNA, and downregulated RAGE mRNA levels by 49% (p<0.05). Immunofluorescence showed that HGA increased RAGE protein levels by 20% and that the addition of VD3 significantly suppressed RAGE protein levels by 44% (p<0.05). CONCLUSIONS: These data indicate that AGEs alter genes involved in steroidogenesis (LHR) and follicular development (AMHR-II) in human GCs in a pattern similar to that observed in PCOS, where LHR and AMHR-II are known to be upregulated. VD3 suppressed RAGE levels and some of the actions of AGEs on GCs. These data provide a crucial missing piece in our understanding of the relationship between diet and ovulatory dysfunction in PCOS.A Novel Method for Detection of Prostaglandins in Human FollicularFluid. Bruce Pier, 1 Jonathon W Edmonds, 1 Ray Moore, 3 Jeevan Prasain, 3 Gordon W Bates, 1 Michael A Miller. 2 1 Div of REI, Dpt of OB/GYN, UABMC, Birmingham, AL, USA; 2 Dpt of Cell, Developmental and Integrative Biology, UAB, Birmingham, AL, USA; 3 Dpt of Pharm and Tox, UAB, Birmingham, AL, USA. INTRODUCTION: Prostaglandins (PG), vital for human ovulation and embryo implantation, have previously been measured in human follicular fluid (HFF) by radioimmunoassay (RIA). Liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectroscopy (LC-MS/MS) is a sensitive and specific method for identifying PG, and may provide an opportunity to present a thorough understanding of the HFF PG content. Our group has used this method to detect novel PGs in C. elegans, which produces PGs independent of a cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme, and demonstrated a role for PGs in reproduction in C. elegans. Our primary aim was to detect PGs in HFF, and secondarily to detect if peaks consistent with COX-independent PG was present in HFF. METHODS: HFF was obtained from patients undergoing oocyte retrieval. Fluid from the first follicle entered on each side was separately collected from each patient. PG extraction was performed on 12 HFF samples. A dueterated standard was added to each sample prior to PG extraction. For PG extraction, a modified liquid-liquid extraction method was used. Extraction efficiency was 70%. LC-MS/MS operated in multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) mode provided PG detection and quantification. PG's were quantified using known concentrations of standard PGs. RESULTS: Varying levels of PGF-2α, PGF-1α, and PGE2 were detected in all samples. Detection of PGE1 and 6-keto PGF-1α did not occur in all samples. PG concentrations are shown inTable 1. The stereoisomers 8-epi-PGF-2α and/or co-eluting 8-epi-15(R) are also commonly detected in our samples. Varying expression of peaks consistent with COX-independent PG were detected as well.CONCLUSIONS: LC-MS/MS provides a novel method for detecting PG. Operated in MRM, LC-MS/MS has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting known PG, and all isomers for the PG in question. We have detected peaks consistent with known PG, as well as COX-independent PG, in HFF. Further research is needed to understand the importance of these findings, to establish a normal PG profile in a fertile population, and to compare a normal profile to subfertile groups to gain insight for the etiology of these subtypes.The Interleukin 11 Gene in OvarianFailure Associated Region 19q13.42 Is Highly Conserved in Women With Premature Ovarian Failure (POF). Robert T Rydze, Ekrem M Bilgin, William E Gibbons, Ertug Kovanci. Obstetrics and Gynecology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX, USA. INTRODUCTION: Genome-wide association studies have identified genetic loci in 19q13.42 region associated with age at natural menopause (ANM) and POF. IL-11 is located in this region of interest and plays a role in immune regulation, specifically in T-cell-dependent development of immunoglobulin-producing B cells.Previous studies have demonstrated that alterations in auto-immune pathways may play a role in ANM and POF. We hypothesized that variations in SNPs within IL-11 may be present in different frequencies in women with POF as compared to the general population. METHODS: We collected genomic DNA from predominantly North American Caucasian women with POF defined as amenorrhea prior to age 40 with elevated FSH >20 IU/L. Primer sets specific for all 5 exons of IL-11 were designed for polymerase chain reaction (PCR). The PCR products were then sequenced using a commercial ABI3730XL Sanger sequencing platform and systematically compared to the human genome database sequence (Ensembl 2014) using Sequencher v5.1 (Gene Codes Corp, Ann Arbor, MI). Electropherograms were manually examined to identify sequence variants. We used 'Sorting Tolerant From Intolerant' (SIFT) and PolyPhen2 software to predict the effect of non-synonymous variants on protein function. RESULTS: In 70 women with POF, we detected one single nucleotide variant (c.98G>A rs4252548) that was predicted to be potentially damaging based on both computational protein function models. However, only one woman with POF demonstrated this variant and the minor allele frequency (MAF) in our cohort was similar to that previously reported in the 1000 Genomes project. No other novel SNPs were identified in any of the exons of IL-11. CONCLUSIONS: All 5 exons of IL-11 are highly conserved in our study population. Therefore, IL-11 mutations are not a common cause of sporadic POF in Caucasians. Our study eliminates another gene in 19q13.42 as a candidate for POF.High Fat Diet Is Associated With Decreased Ovarian ReserveIrrespective of Obese Phenotype. Malgorzata E Skaznik-Wikiel, Jennifer Monks, Elise S Bales, Alex J Polotsky, James L McManaman. Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of Colorado Denver, Aurora, CO, USA. INTRODUCTION: Obesity is associated with decreased ovarian reserve and impaired reproduction. However, it is unclear if these effects are due to adiposity per se or to high dietary fats. We sought to determine the relative effects of high fat feeding versus obesity on ovarian reserve in mice. METHODS: Sexually mature 9 wk old C57BL/6 mice were assigned to receive different dietary interventions for 8 weeks. Group I (n=3) received low fat diet (LFD) including 10% of calories coming from fat resulting in lean phenotype (LF-Ln). Group II (n=3) was fed high fat diet (HFD) with 60% of calories coming from fat resulting in obesity (HF-Ob). Group III (n=4) was fed HFD resulting in lean phenotype (HF-Ln). Ovaries were collected after 8 weeks of dietary exposure for assessment of resting (primordial) and growing (primary, secondary, antral) follicle numbers. Animal weights were recorded and percentage of body fat was measured using whole-body MRI at the time of ovary collection. Student t-test and one-way ANOVA were used as appropriate (GraphPad Prism 6).RESULTS:The average weights of the animals in LF-Ln, HF-Ob, and HF-Ln groups were 20.5±0.5g, 27.3±1.5g, and 21.7±1.2g, respectively. Respective mean fat mass values for each group were 14.2±3.1%, 26.2±2.6%, and 16.7±5.4%. While HF-Ob group had significantly higher adiposity, the mean body weight and fat mass were not statistically different between LF-Ln and HF-Ln group (p=0.13). Based on dietary intervention, primordial follicle numbers were 928±39 in LFD mice and 445±78 in HFD mice (p=0.005). Exposure to HFD resulted in decreased ovarian reserve (depleted primordial follicles) irrespective of obese phenotype. Primordial follicle numbers were 577±114 in HF-Ob and 346±84 in HF-Ln animals compared to 928±39 in LF-Ln mice (p=0.006). *Figure(s) will be available online. Numbers of primary, secondary, and antral follicles did not differ significantly between the three groups. CONCLUSIONS: HFD results in decreased ovarian reserve, irrespective of obesity. Our findings support the notion that high fat diet could play a role in the causal link between obesity and impaired reproduction.NKT-Activation Alters the Maternal T-Cell Repertoire and CausesPreterm Birth. Marcia Arenas-Hernandez, 1 Derek St Louis, 1,2 Elly N Sanchez-Rodriguez, 1 Roberto Romero, 2 Nardhy Gomez-Lopez. 1,2 1 OB/ GYN, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, USA; 2 Perinatology Research Branch, NICHD/NIH, Detroit/Bethesda, MI/MD, USA. INTRODUCTION: Activation of NKT cells with α-Galactosylceramide (α-GalCer) induces preterm birth (PTB) (StLouis et al, unpublished data).

TABREF512.text: By Preclampsia. Ofer Fainaru, Shay Hantisteanu, Gili Paz, Ofer Limonad, Mordechai Hallak. IVF Unit and Laboratory for ReproductiveImmunology, Hillel Yaffe  Medical Center, Technion -Israel Institute of Technology, Hadera, NA,  Israel.   INTRODUCTION: Myeloid cell populations have been shown to play role in angiogenesis. For example, immature myeloid cells (IMCs) that differentiate into granulocytes, monocytes, macrophages and dendritic cells (DCs), promote angiogenesis in malignancies but also in the placenta. We tested whether placental development is accompanied by alterations in myeloid cell populations and whether preeclampsia is associated with aberrations in their presence. METHODS: Mouse experiments: placentas were harvested from pregnancies of C57Bl/6 and Cx3CR1 GFP/+ mice. Human experiments: placentas were obtained from normal vaginal deliveries (NVD) and from elective cesarean-sections (CS) or from pregnancies with preeclampsia. Placentas were immunostained and analysed using flow cytometry. Immunohistochemistry was performed on frozen sections. RESULTS: The percentage of CD11b high CX3CR1GFPneutrophils of total CD45 + cells in mouse placentas peaked before labor (28.3±7.9%, 17.6±9.3%, 30.4±2.3% on days 12,15,19 ;n=25, p=0.006). Conversely, both CD11b + CX3CR1GFP int monocytes and CD11b + CX3CR1GFP high macrophages decreased throughout pregnancy (21.5±5.3%, 16.7±3.6%, 10.6±3.4% and 6.4±2.4%, 4.4 ±2.9 % 1.8±0.4%;n=25, p=0.001, p=0.035). CD11b + Gr1 + IMCs decreased throughout the latter part of pregnancy (29±9.1%, 30±9.9% ,21±8.1%; n=63, P=0.004) while CD11c + MHCII + DCs increased before labor (0.87±0.3% ,0.7±0.3%, 1.81±1.3%; n=63, P=0.001). In placenta tissue sections IMCs and not DCs located adjacent to CD31 + endothelial cells lining blood vessels. Similarly, the CD11c + HLADR + DC population was higher in human placentas from NVD compared to CS (6.7±3.36% vs. 4.7±1.98%, n=41, P=0.03). The CD45 + lin2 -CD33 + HLADR -IMC population in placentas from patients with preeclampsia was higher compared to those obtained from healthy controls (17.7±7.35% vs. 9.4±3.8%, n=14, P=0.018). CONCLUSIONS: In mouse placentas monocytes, macrophages and IMCs decrease throughout pregnancy paralleling a reciprocal increase in neutrophils and DCs. This accords with proangiogenic properties of the former-and proinflammatory properties of the latter populations. In line with mouse data, human placental DCs increased in labor (NVD) as compared with the absence of labor (CS). In preeclampsia the increase in IMCs may result from placental hypoxia and the need for increased angiogenesis.Prenatal Stress Over Generations Disrupts the T-Cell Repertoire inMothers and Neonates. Amy-Eunice Furcron, 1 Tara N Mial, 1 Marcia Arenas-Hernandez, 1 Roberto Romero, 2 Sonia S Hassan, 1,2 Nardhy Gomez-Lopez. 1,2 1 OB/GYN, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, USA;  2 Perinatology Research Branch, NICHD/NIH, Detroit/Bethesda, MI/  MD, USA.   INTRODUCTION: Prenatal stress is associated with maternal and neonatal adverse events. Our preliminary data demonstrate that prenatal stress over 2-3 generations shortens gestational length, reduces neonatal weight, and increases the rate of neonatal and infant mortality(Furcron  et al, unpublished data). A breakdown of the maternal and neonatal immune systems may be associated with these events. We hypothesized that prenatal stress over 2-3 generations disrupts the T-cell repertoire in mothers and their neonates. METHODS: B6 dams were stressed over 3 generations: F0S, F1SS, and F2SSS. F1SS, F2SSS, and control (non-stressed) dams (n=5-7)

Tom EC Kieffer, 1 Marijke M Faas, 2 Sicco A Scherjon, 1 Jelmer R Prins. 1 1 Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, University Medical Center, Groningen, Netherlands; 2 Department of Pathology and Medical Biology, University Medical Center, Groningen, Netherlands. INTRODUCTION:

TABREF514.text: Epigenetic Regulation of Macrophage Polarization By First TrimesterDecidual Cells. Longzhu Piao, 1 Xianqing Wu, 1,2 Vrajesh Karkhanis, 3 Said Sif, 3 Frederick Schatz, 4 Charles J Lockwood, 4 S Joseph Huang. 1 1Obstetrics and Gynecology, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH,  USA; 2 Obstetrics and Gynecology, Xiangya Second Hospital, Central  South University, Changsha, Hunan, China; 3  Molecular and Cellular  Biochemistry, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, USA; 4  Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of South Florida, Tampa, FL, USA. INTRODUCTION: Spontaneous abortion (SA) complicates 5 -10% of pregnancies. Previous results suggest that macrophages (MFs) play a pivotal role during the pathogenesis of SA by polarizing to an M1 subtype under the influence of first trimester decidual cells (FTDCs). Mf polarization is regulated by histone modification at the promoter of marker genes. Interferon regulatory factor 7 (IRF7) is suggested to play a role in MΦ differentiation via epigenetic mechanisms. Like histone lysine methylation, methylation of histone arginine residues can also regulate transcription with protein arginine methyltransferase 5 (PRMT5) playing a crucial role in this process. However, the role of PRMT5 and IRF7 in MΦ polarization has not been demonstrated. Thus, we hypothesize that FTDCs direct MΦ polarization via PRMT5 and IRF-associated epigenetic regulation. METHODS: FTDCs were primed with estradiol (10 -8 M) + medroxyprogesterone acetate (10 -7 M) for 7d followed by adding 1 ng/ml of interleukin-1β (IL-1β) or tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α). Peripheral monocytes (MOs) were then incubated with conditioned media (CM) from FTDC cultures for 5d. IRF7 expression by MFs was assessed by qRT-PCR and by Western blotting. In parallel experiments, MOs were also treated with M1 stimuli using recombinant human granulocyte MΦ-colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF; 50 ng/mL) for 5d followed by lipopolysaccharide (LPS; 100 ng/mL) and interferon-γ(IFN-γ; 20 ng/mL) ± a PRMT5 inhibitor, compound 5 (CMP5) for 24h. Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assay examined the presence of PRMT5 in IRF7 promoter. The expression of PRMT5 and IRF7 in MFs was evaluated using qRT-PCR and Western blotting. RESULTS: qRT-PCR and Western blot consistently showed an increase of IRF7 in MOs cultured with CM from IL-1β-or TNF-α-treated FTDCs. M1 stimuli increased PRMT5 recruitment to IRF7 promoter by 3.45-fold. PRMT5 and IRF7 expression was induced by M1 stimuli by 4.16-and 10.43-fold, respectively. The induction of IRF7 expression in MFs was inhibited by CMP5. CONCLUSIONS: These results suggest that PRMT5 is involved in the regulation of IRF7 which is associated with FTDC-induced M1 MΦ polarization.Longitudinal Changes in Dendritic Cells Response To Toll-Like Receptor Stimulation in Uncomplicated Pregnancy andPostpartum. Aleksandar K Stanic, 2 Brett C Young, 1 Anatte E Karmon, 1 Bo R Rueda. 1 Vincent Center for Reproductive Biology, Vincent Ob/Gyn, Massachusetts General Hospital/Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, USA; 2 Div Reproductive Sciences, Dept Ob/Gyn, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA. INTRODUCTION: Alterations in expression and function of Toll-like receptors (TLR) have been implicated in pregnancy complications. However, dendritic cell (DC) TLR reactivity across the span of normal pregnancy and postpartum is unknown. Objective was to evaluate DC cytokine response to

TABREF515.text: Proportion of DCs producing cytokine (all p<0.05) CONCLUSIONS: Systematic changes in TLR responsiveness are demonstrated across pregnancy and postpartum, allowing for hypothesisdriven testing of this system in pregnancy physiology and pathology. TABREF516.text: Exosomal MicroRNAs: Implications for Immune Tolerance. Adrianne L Stefanski, 1 Lisa K Peterson, 1 Marisa E Luck, 1 Eric Treacy, 1 Amy Hermesch, 1 Emin Maltepe, 2 Tzu L Phang, 1 Leonard L Dragone, 1,3 Virginia D Winn. 1 1 Obstetrics & Gynecology, University of Colorado AMC, Aurora, CO, USA; 2 Pediatrics/Neonatology, University of California, San Francisco, CA, USA; 3 Pediatrics, National Jewish Health, Denver, CO, USA. INTRODUCTION: Exosomes are small extracellular vesicles released by cells, which contain microRNAs(miRNAs). During gestation, the placenta releases large quantities of exosomes into the maternal circulation. We hypothesized that placentally-derived exosomes aid establishment of maternal-fetal tolerance and rheumatoid arthritis (RA) amelioration in pregnancy via miRNA transfer to immune cells. To facilitate mechanistic studies in mice, the first goal was to determine the miRNA profiles of trophoblast and pregnancy-associated exosomes. METHODS: Next-generation RNA-sequencing was used to identify miRNAs contained in exosomes derived from undifferentiated murine trophoblast stem cells (TSC), TSC cells differentiated to syncytium (SynT), as well as nonpregnant (NP) and 14.5 day pregnant (GD14.5) B6 mice, n=3 per group. Selected miRNAs were further investigated by qRT-PCR from TSC and SynT (n=5) and NP and GD14.5 (n=8) exosomes. RESULTS: Four miRNAs were differentially abundant (increased: miR-322, miR-450a; decreased: miR-5099, miR-1198) in SynT compared to TSC exosomes (p<0.05). qRT-PCR revealed miR-322 enrichment in both pregnancy (322-3p, p=0.0004; 322-5p, p=0.001) and SynT differentiation (322-3p, p=0.0093; 322-5p, p=0.0004). Interestingly, three additional microRNAs (503-5p, 542-3p, 450a-5p) that cluster with miRNA-322 were also increased with SynT differentiation (p=0.0485, p=0.0012, and p<0.0001); 503-5p also increased with pregnancy (p=0.0014). Exosomal miR-292-3p was detected by RNA-sequencing in GD14.5 but not in NP exosomes, and by qRT-PCR miRNA-292-3p increased with pregnancy (p=0.0035). CONCLUSIONS: Pregnancy-associated and trophoblast exosomes contain a cluster of miRNAs around miR-322, which is known to be abundant in mouse placenta. The human ortholog of miR-322, hsa-miR-424, is known to increase with primary human trophoblast syncytialization. Gene targets of hsa-miR-424 (FGFR1, CUL2), hsa-miR-503 (FGF2) and mmu-miR-292 (DKK1) have been implicated in immune modulation and RA. Future studies will address functional and immunologic consequences of these syncytial and pregnancy-associated exosomal miRNAs.Funding: ACR (LLD), CTSA TL1 TR000155 (ALS), T32 HD07186 (AH), UC SOM (VDW, LLD) Effect of Heme Oxygenase-1 on the immunosuppressive Function of DecIdual Myeloid Cells. Hui Zhao, Flora Kalish, Ronald J Wong, David K Stevenson. Pediatrics, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Myeloid cells, such as macrophages (MΦ), dendritic cells (DCs) and neutrophils, infiltrate into the decidua in early pregnancy and promote immunotolerance to support placental and fetal development. Myeloid subtypes with suppressive properties [alternatively-activated MΦ (M2s), tolerogenic DCs (tDCs), and myeloid derived suppressive cells (MDSCs)], have been identified in human and mouse deciduae. The stress-response protein, heme oxygenase-1(HO-1), has anti-inflammatory functions, can facilitate immunotolerance in organ transplantation, and is highly expressed in the decidua. A deficiency in HO-1 is associated with spontaneous abortions. Since HO-1 is involved in the polarization of M2s and tolerogenicity of DCs, we hypothesize that HO-1 may also regulate immunosuppressive functions of decidual myeloid cells. METHODS: Deciduae were collected at E8.5, 9.5, and 10.5 from timed pregnancies of wild-type (WT) FVB or HO-1 deficient (HO-1 +/-, Het) breeding pairs. Gene expression profiles of ~17 cytokines/chemokines were measured by PCR arrays and compared between WT and Het deciduae. Single cell suspensions from deciduae were stained with antibodies for surface or intracellular markers. Flow cytometry was used to analyse myeloid cell types: infiltrating MΦ (CD11b hi Ly6C hi ), DCs (CD11b hi CD11c + ), neutrophils (CD11b hi Ly6-G hi ), residential MΦ (CD11b mid F4/80 + ), uterine natural killer (uNK) cells (DBA + ), etc. M2s or tDCs were also characterized. HO-1 levels were assessed by intracellular staining. RESULTS: At E10.5, mRNA levels of chemokines (Ccl1, Ccl6, Ccl11, Ccl12, Cxcl4, Cxcl9, Cxcl12), interleukins (Il-6, Il15, Il-16 and Il-17b), receptors (Ccr1, Ccr2, Ccr3, Ccr5, Il1r1), and myeloid pan-marker CD11b were significantly reduced in HO-1 Het deciduae. HO-1 was primarily expressed in infiltrating myeloid cells and low in uNK cells and residential MΦ. In WT deciduae, 50% of CD11b mid F4/80 + MΦ were CD206 + M2s; while the majority of CD11C + DCs were CD80 -CD86 -MHCii -tDCs. Compared to WT deciduae, uNK cells and neutrophils/MDSCs were significantly less in HO-1 Het deciduae at E9.5. Also, without any change in the total DC population, the percentage of tDCs was significantly reduced in Het deciduae at E9.5 and E10.5. CONCLUSIONS: A deficiency in maternal HO-1 expression results in significant alterations in cytokines/chemokines production and composition of immunosuppressive myeloid subtypes in deciduae and, therefore may affect immunotolerance during early pregnancy.B Cell Autorreactivity Potential Is Repressed During HumanPregnancy.Katharina Ziegler, Damian Muzzio, Imke Bommer, Franziska  Matzner, Kristin Malinowsky, Marek Zygmunt, Federico Jensen. Research  Laboratory: Obstetrics and Gynecology, Universitätsmedizin Greifswald,  Greifswald, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany.   INTRODUCTION: B lymphocytes are pleiotropic cells belonging to the adaptive arm of the immune system. Although B cells were classically regarded for their capacity to produce antibodies, in the recent years, several other functions were attributed to these cells. Two major B cell subpopulations B1 and B2 have been described. The human B2 cells develop postnatally from hematopoietic precursor cells in the bone marrow to pro-B cells, pre-B cells to immature B cells, which can egress into the blood circulation. Unlike B2, the B1 cells develop in the fetal liver and are maintained in the adult life by self-replenishment. Whereas B1 CD11bcells subpopulation is a major source antibodies, CD11b + B1 B cells secrete significant amounts of anti-inflammatory cytokine IL10, involved in the process of pregnancy tolerance. In this study the expression of different populations of B cells was examined in pregnant and non-pregnant women. METHODS: 124 women were included in our cross-sectional study. They were assigned to five groups: non-pregnant, 1st, 2nd, 3rd trimester and postpartum. Isolated PBMCs were stained for extra-and intracellular markers and analyzed by flow cytometry. FlowJo software was used for analysis. Statistical significance was assessed by the nonparametric Oneway ANOVA Kruskal-Wallis Test. RESULTS: Our data shows an accumulation of early pro-pre B cells (CD24 bright CD38 bright CD10 + IgM -)in peripheral blood of pregnant women in first trimester as compared to non-pregnant age-matched control women. Further analysis depicted a statistical significant decrease of the higher differentiated immature B cells (CD24 bright CD38 bright CD10 low IgM + ) in pregnant women in second trimester compared to non-pregnant women.

TABREF518.text: Does Race Affect the Rate of Cervical Shortening? Daphnie Drassinower, Cande V Ananth, Heather Levin, Sarah G Obican, Leslie Moroz, Joy Vink. Obstetrics and Gynecology, Columbia University Medical Center, New York, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION: African American women have an increased risk of preterm birth(PTB). We sought to determine whether African American women have a faster rate of cervical shortening compared to other races.METHODS:We performed a secondary analysis of the Preterm Prediction Study, a multicenter prospective observational study that investigated risk factors for PTB. Women had cervical length (CL) measurements at 22-24 and 26-28 weeks and were followed until delivery.

Aurelija Dubicke, 1 Gunvor Ekman-Ordeberg, 1 Lindsey Miller, 2 Trish Mazurek, 2 Steven M Yellon. 2 1 Deparment of Women's and Children's Health, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden; 2 Deparment of Basic Sciences, Division of Physiology and Pediatrics, Center for Perinatal Biology, Loma Linda University School of Medicine, Loma Linda, CA, USA. TABREF520.text: Under Oxidative Stress. Liping Feng, 1 Terrence K Allen, 2 Amy P Murtha. 1 1 OB-GYN, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, USA;  2 Anesthesiology, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, USA.   INTRODUCTION: The chorioamnion is vulnerable to oxidative stress (OS). OS mediated telomere shortening (cell aging or cellular senescence marker) in the fetal membranes is a normal physiologic process leading to term delivery, but is activated prematurely in preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM). We also demonstrated that chorion cell death and extracellular matrix degradation resulted in chorion layer thinning in PPROM. Sirtuin1 (SIRT1) and Sirtuin 3 (SIRT3) deacetylate several proteins that promote resistance to OS and DNA damage. Progestins protect cytotrophoblast cells (lack of nuclear progesterone receptors) from cell death likely mediated through progesterone membrane component 1 (PGRMC1) (our published data). Therefore, we aim to investigate the role of progesterone and PGRMC1 in the regulation of SIRT1 and SIRT3 in chorion cells in the setting of OS (H 2 O 2 exposure). METHODS: Primary chorion cells were treated with H 2 O 2 at 100, 300, 500µM for 4h and 24h with or without pretreatment with P4 or Ethanol (vehicle) at a dose of 10 -7 M for 1h. Cell lysates were harvested for Western blotting to determine SIRT1 and SIRT3 expressions. To examine the role of PGRMC1, primary chorion cells were treated the same way mentioned above after knock down PGRMC1 using specific siRNA. Cell lysates were harvested for Western blotting to determine knockdown of PGRMC1 expression and SIRT1 and SIRT3 expressions. GAPDH was used as internal control. Experiments are replicated using fetal membrane tissues from 7 subjects. RESULTS: H 2 O 2 significantly down-regulated SIRT3 protein expression (but not SIRT1) in a dose and time dependent manner. The downregulation of SIRT3 by H 2 O 2 was inhibited by P4 pretreatment. The down-regulation of SIRT1 and SIRT3 by H 2 O 2 was significantly increased in PGRMC1 knock down cells compared to wild type control cells. However, the inhibition of SIRT down-regulation by P4 pretreatment was not significantly different in PGRMC1 knock down cells and control cells. Thus the P4 effect in this process does not solely depend on PGRMC1. CONCLUSIONS: SIRTs are important in the physiologic process of cell aging. Our findings demonstrate the critical role of P4 and PGRMC1 in SIRT regulation in chorion cells under OS. In a broader view, the involvement of PGRMC1 in SIRT regulation is novel and can be critical for other OS and aging related disease conditions.Biomechanical Simulations of Pregnancy: The Effects of Collagen Stiffness and Membrane Adhesion on Cervical Deformation andShortening. M Fernandez, 1 M House, 2 S Jambawalikar, 3 J Vink, 4 N Zork, 4 R Wapner, 4 K Myers. 1 1 MechanicalEngineering, Columbia University,  New York, NY, USA; 2 Obstetrics and Gynecology & MFM, Tufts Medical  Center, Boston, MA, USA; 3 Radiology, Columbia University Medical  Center, New York, NY, USA; 4 Division of Maternal Fetal Medicine,  Columbia University Medical Center, New York, NY, USA.   INTRODUCTION: The biomechanical factors leading to a short cervix cannot be accurately studied in pregnant patients. Mechanical simulations such as the finite element (FE) method are well suited to study these factors. We hypothesized that three factors have an important impact on cervical shortening: cervical collagen properties, fetal membrane adhesion, and intrauterine pressure (IUP). We built a FE model to test this hypothesis by varying one model parameter at a time and simulating mechanical loads from IUP. METHODS: Two patients were recruited: 32 y/o P0 at 28 weeks with normal cervical length and 25 y/o P2 at 22 weeks with a short cervix.

Arturo Flores-Pliego, 1 Marisol Castillo-Castrejon, 2 Noemi Meraz-Cruz, 2 Aurora Espejel Nunez, 1 Veronica Zaga, 1 Felipe Vadillo-Ortega, 2 Guadalupe Estrada-Gutierrez. 1 1 Research Direction, Instituto Nacional de Perinatología, Mexico City, D.F., Mexico; 2 Unidad de Vinculación de la Facultad de Medicina, Instituto Nacional de Medicina Genómica, Mexico City, D.F., Mexico. INTRODUCTION: Rupture of the fetal membranes is the last event in normal labor or the unique clinical feature in the premature rupture of the membranes. This phenomenon is the result of extracellular matrix degradation and preliminary studies have identified leukocytes circulating in the placental blood and infiltrating the choriodecidua as the source of proteases.
